{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18794,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thalictrum aquilegiifolium prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season. It is essential to water this plant regularly, ensuring that the soil does not dry out completely. However, avoid overwatering to prevent root rot; the soil should be moist but not waterlogged. During dry periods or when grown in containers, increase the frequency of watering. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain a steady level of humidity. Reduce watering in the dormant winter months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thalictrum aquilegiifolium thrives in partial shade, although it can tolerate full sun in cooler climates. Under full sunlight, the plant may require additional watering to prevent the soil from drying out. If grown in hotter, more intense sun regions, provide some afternoon shade to protect the plant from excessive heat stress. Too much shade, however, can lead to weaker stems and less flowering. Ideally, provide morning sun and afternoon shade for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thalictrum aquilegiifolium is generally minimal and is mostly done to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage bushier growth. Deadhead spent flowers to prolong the blooming period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. In late fall or early spring, cut back any dead or damaged stems to ground level to make way for new growth. Removing old stems not only keeps the plant healthy but also reduces the risk of fungal diseases. Be cautious when handling, as the sap can be irritating to sensitive skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"French meadow-rue","description":"Thalictrum aquilegiifolium is a species of flowering plant in the Ranunculaceae (buttercup) family known by the common names Siberian columbine meadow-rue, columbine meadow-rue, French meadow-rue, and greater meadow-rue. Its native range extends through Europe and temperate Asia, with a naturalized distribution in North America limited to New York and Ontario.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["French meadow-rue"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Leafhoppers"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Thalictrum aquilegiifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18393,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Russula sanguinea, like many wild mushrooms, does not require watering in the traditional sense. Instead, these mushrooms thrive in naturally moist environments, often found on the forest floor. Mimicking these conditions is essential if attempting to cultivate them. Ensuring a humid environment, with adequate moisture in the soil or substrate, is necessary, but care should be taken to avoid waterlogging, as excess water can lead to mold and decay. Air circulation is crucial to prevent excessive moisture accumulation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Russula sanguinea mushrooms typically grow in shaded, forested areas and thrive in low-light conditions. Direct sunlight should be avoided as these mushrooms can dry out rapidly under such exposure. Instead, they prefer dappled sunlight or indirect lighting environments that mimic the understorey conditions of their natural habitat. If growing indoors or in controlled environments, using ambient artificial light to provide a consistent, low-intensity light source can help recreate their natural growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Russula sanguinea mushrooms do not require pruning as they are not traditional plants with branches or leaves. However, during cultivation, removing any decaying or diseased specimens promptly is advised to maintain a healthy growing environment and to prevent the spread of pathogens. Dead or decaying materials can attract pests and diseases, so maintaining cleanliness in and around the growth area can help preserve the overall health of the fungal habitat."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bloody brittlegill","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["bloody brittlegill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Russula sanguinea"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19689,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronica salicifolia, commonly known as koromiko, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It's essential not to let the plant dry out completely between waterings. In hotter months, water regularly to ensure the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged, which can lead to root rot. In cooler months, reduce watering and allow the top layer of soil to dry slightly before re-watering. Mulching can help maintain soil moisture levels. Always consider the local climate and soil conditions to adjust the watering schedule appropriately."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronica salicifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure optimal growth and blooming. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent overheating and dehydration. In cooler climates, placing it in a location with maximum sunlight exposure is recommended. Too much shade can result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. Ensure the plant is protected from harsh afternoon sun, especially in peak summer, to avoid leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Veronica salicifolia is beneficial to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune after flowering, usually in late spring or early summer, to remove spent flower spikes and any dead or diseased wood. Trim back overgrown stems to encourage bushier growth and enhance air circulation. A general rule is not to remove more than one-third of the plant's total growth at one time. Avoid pruning too late in the season, as new growth might not harden off before winter. Always use sharp and sterilized tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"koromiko","description":"Hebe salicifolia, the koromiko, or willow-leaf hebe, is a plant of the family Plantaginaceae, which is found throughout the South Island of New Zealand and in Chile. It is large, evergreen shrub, reaching 2 m in height, with light green, spear-shaped leaves that are up to 12 cm long. Flowers are white or pale lilac.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["koromiko"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Veronica salicifolia"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19385,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lampranthus bicolor, like many succulents, requires careful watering to avoid overwatering. It is best to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season in the warmer months, water the plant thoroughly but infrequently. In winter, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the leaves from shriveling. This plant is drought-tolerant, so it is more forgiving to underwatering than to overwatering, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lampranthus bicolor thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its vibrant colors and compact growth. If planted outdoors, choose a location with ample sunshine. When grown indoors, place it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive plenty of light. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. In extremely hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense sun exposure, preventing scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lampranthus bicolor involves removing dead or damaged stems and leaves to maintain its appearance and stimulate healthy growth. After flowering, you can trim back the spent blooms and leggy stems to encourage bushier growth. Regular pruning also helps in managing the size of the plant, especially if grown in containers or confined spaces. Use clean and sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts, thereby reducing the risk of diseases. Avoid heavy pruning during the dormancy period in winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Twocolour Brightfig","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Twocolour Brightfig"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Lampranthus bicolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18291,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phoradendron villosum, commonly known as a type of mistletoe, does not require direct watering as it is a parasitic plant. It primarily absorbs moisture and nutrients from its host tree. In cultivation, it's essential to maintain the health of the host plant and ensure it has adequate water supply. If grown independently for study purposes, ensure the medium is consistently moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to rot. Monitoring the host plant’s needs will indirectly guide the watering approach for the mistletoe."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phoradendron villosum generally thrives in filtered sunlight, matching the light conditions of its typical host environment in woodlands. Since it usually grows attached to tree branches, it is accustomed to dappled sunlight that filters through the canopy. In cultivation, mimic these conditions by providing bright, indirect light. Direct exposure to harsh sunlight can dry out the plant, whereas too little light might inhibit growth. Observing its natural habitat gives clues to optimizing light conditions for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Phoradendron villosum should be minimal and mainly for control or health purposes. Since it's a parasitic plant, significant pruning might harm its delicate attachment to the host. Carefully remove only overly dense or dead sections to encourage better air circulation and reduce disease risk. Conduct any pruning during the dormant season of the host plant to minimize stress. Ensure cuts are clean to prevent infection, and observe the host plant’s response to ensure overall health is maintained."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"oak mistletoe","description":"Phoradendron villosum is a species of flowering plant in the sandalwood family known by the common names Pacific mistletoe and oak mistletoe. It is native to western North America from Oregon south into Mexico, where it grows in oak woodland and similar habitat.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["oak mistletoe"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mistletoe syndrome"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phoradendron villosum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19193,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tolypocladium ophioglossoides, primarily a fungus, does not require traditional watering like a plant. Instead, it requires humid conditions suitable for mushroom growth. If cultivating this fungus\nindoors, ensure that the environment has adequate humidity, usually between 85-95%, and maintain indirect moisture by using methods like misting or closed terrarium setups. Be cautious not to oversaturate the growing medium, as excess moisture can lead to unfavorable conditions for fungal growth. Keep the medium slightly moist by monitoring the substrate's dampness regularly, adjusting as needed to create an ideal humid environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Unlike plants, Tolypocladium ophioglossoides does not require direct sunlight as it is a fungus and not photosynthetic. Instead, it requires low light conditions or indirect light, similar to the environments mushrooms typically thrive in. When cultivating, ensure it has a dark to dimly lit environment, mimicking its natural habitat below the forest canopy. Over-exposure to direct sunlight can cause the substrate to dry out and negatively impact the fungus' growth. Ensure indirect light is gentle and complement it with the right humidity and temperature conditions for successful cultivation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't a conventional care practice required for Tolypocladium ophioglossoides, as it is a fungus rather than a plant. The main concern with cultivating this organism is ensuring the proper conditions for its growth, free from competing molds or contaminating species. Cleanliness is key in maintaining a healthy substrate. If growing this fungus in a controlled environment, regular checks for mold growth or contamination are necessary. If contamination occurs, carefully remove affected areas and sterilize the environment to prevent further issues. Basic hygiene practices surrounding its cultivation environment are crucial for optimal growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Snaketongue Truffleclub","description":"Tolypocladium ophioglossoides, also known by two of its better known synonyms Elaphocordyceps ophioglossoides and Cordyceps ophioglossoides and commonly known as the goldenthread cordyceps, is a species of fungus in the family Ophiocordycipitaceae. It is parasitic on fruit bodies of the truffle-like Elaphomyces. The specific epithet ophioglossoides, derived from Ancient Greek, means \"like a snake's tongue\".","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Snaketongue Truffleclub"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Tolypocladium ophioglossoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19589,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oxalis commutata prefers continuously moist soil, so it's important to water it regularly. However, the soil should not be waterlogged as this can cause root rot. Ensure that the soil drains well, and reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. A good practice is to let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings. During the growing season, usually spring through early fall, you can water the plant more frequently to maintain the necessary moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxalis commutata thrives best in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it’s important to find a location where it can benefit from filtered light. An east or west-facing window where the plant receives morning or late afternoon sun is ideal. In lower light conditions, the plant may become leggy and may not bloom as prolifically. If indoors, rotate the plant occasionally to ensure even lighting on all sides, and consider using a grow light if adequate natural light is unavailable."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oxalis commutata is relatively simple; it involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's aesthetic appearance. Prune away any stems and flower stalks that have finished blooming to prevent the plant from using energy on seed production. Regularly check the plant and trim any browning or damaged leaves. This should be done throughout the growing season to help the plant remain healthy and vigorous. Pruning also helps the plant maintain a tidy and bushy shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alternating Sorrel","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Alternating Sorrel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Oxalis commutata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18887,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arctotheca populifolia, commonly known as dune daisy or beach daisy, requires minimal watering. As a coastal plant, it is adapted to dry, sandy environments and is drought-tolerant. Water the plant sparingly, ensuring the soil is allowed to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other fungal issues. In its natural habitat, rainwater is usually sufficient, but during prolonged periods of drought or extremely hot weather, you can supplement with a light watering once every couple of weeks."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arctotheca populifolia thrives in full sunlight, which helps the plant produce its characteristic bright yellow flowers abundantly. Aim to provide it with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to meet its light requirements successfully. This plant is well adapted to coastal environments and can tolerate high levels of sun exposure, making it ideal for open, sunny areas. While it can survive in partial shade, too much shade may reduce flowering and affect its overall growth and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arctotheca populifolia is generally minimal, as it tends to maintain a natural, spreading habit. However, you can remove any dead, damaged, or leggy stems to encourage more vigorous growth and a tidier appearance. Pruning can be done at any time of the year, but it's best to avoid doing so during the plant's flowering period to not reduce blooms. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, and remove old flower heads promptly to encourage continuous blooming through the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Beach Daisy","description":"Arctotheca populifolia is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common names beach daisy, Cape beach daisy, South African beach daisy, coast capeweed, dune arctotheca, beach pumpkin, sea pumpkin, dune cabbage, and in South Africa, seepampoen, tonteldoek, and strandgousblom. This species is native to South Africa. It was introduced to Australia and is now a common weed of coastal areas in New South Wales, South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria, and Western Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Beach Daisy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Arctotheca populifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19087,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polygala fruticosa, or sweet pea shrub, prefers well-drained soil and requires moderate watering. It is important to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly but less frequently. In contrast, reduce the watering in winter when the plant is dormant. Aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Overwatering can harm the plant more than underwatering, so always check the top layer of soil to ensure it has dried out a bit before the next watering session."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygala fruticosa thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, this plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote robust flowering. However, it can tolerate some light shade, especially in hotter climates, where afternoon shade might protect it from intense sun. If grown indoors, placing it near a bright window where it receives ample sunlight throughout the day will ensure optimal growth. Too little sunlight may result in fewer blooms and leggy growth, so balance is key for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Polygala fruticosa in early spring to encourage bushiness and remove any dead or damaged branches. Light pruning throughout the growing season can also help maintain shape and promote a more compact growth habit. After flowering, deadhead spent blossoms to encourage more blooms. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18588,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Osmanthus fragrans, also known as fragrant tea olive, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It's important to water the plant deeply and then allow the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. During the growing season, spring through summer, it may require more frequent watering, approximately once a week. In the dormant winter period, reduce watering as the plant needs less moisture but do not let the soil completely dry out. Always consider humidity levels and rainfall in your area to adjust the frequency of watering accordingly to avoid overwatering and root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Osmanthus fragrans thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight for optimal blooming. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching and reduce stress on the plant. If grown indoors, place the plant in a bright, south-facing window. It's adaptable to various light conditions but may produce fewer flowers if kept in too much shade. Watch for signs such as leggy growth or reduced flowering, which indicate the plant needs more light. Adjust the location gradually to acclimate the plant to its new light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Osmanthus fragrans to maintain shape and encourage new growth. Best done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any dead, damaged, or crossed branches. You can also trim back the tips of branches to control size and shape or to stimulate denser foliage. If you are shaping a hedge, regular light pruning throughout the growing season is acceptable. Be cautious not to over-prune as this may reduce blooming, since flowers form on the previous year's growth. Lightly thinning the plant helps improve air circulation and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sweet olive","description":"Osmanthus fragrans (lit. \"fragrant osmanthus\"; Chinese: 桂花, guìhuā, and 木樨, mùxī; Cantonese Yale: gwai fā; Japanese: 木犀, mokusei; Hindi: सिलंग, silang), variously known as sweet osmanthus, sweet olive, tea olive, and fragrant olive, is a species native to Asia from the Himalayas through southern China (Guizhou, Sichuan, Yunnan) to Taiwan and southern Japan and southeast Asia as far south as Cambodia and Thailand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan"],"other_name":["Sweet olive"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Osmanthus fragrans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18795,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thelymitra pulchella, commonly known as the sun orchid, requires careful watering to mimic its natural environment. It prefers a dry period in the dormant stage (summer) and adequate moisture during the growing season (autumn and winter). Water the plant regularly during its growth period, but avoid waterlogging which can cause root rot. Ensure the soil is well-drained, and it is best to allow the top layer of the soil to slightly dry out between waterings. Use rainwater or distilled water if possible, as they replicate the plant's natural habitat conditions better than tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thelymitra pulchella thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, similar to its natural habitat. It prefers morning sun or dappled shade if grown outdoors, which helps to mimic its native environment conditions. When grown indoors or in a greenhouse, place the plant near a south-facing window with filtered light. Avoid direct harsh afternoon sun, as it can scorch the leaves. If the light level is too low, it might not bloom. Therefore, ensuring it receives the right amount of sunlight is crucial for its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thelymitra pulchella is generally minimal. After flowering and during its dormant period, remove any dead or dying flowers and leaves to direct the plant’s energy into new growth when it begins its active phase again. Once mature, it generally requires watering only during extended dry periods. Reduce watering significantly during the winter months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Terminalia mantaly prefers full sun to partial shade but thrives best with at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Prune in late winter or early spring while the plant is dormant. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches first. Thin out any crowded areas to allow light and air to penetrate the inner branches, promoting healthy growth. Trim back any branches that disrupt the layered appearance to maintain the plant’s aesthetic appeal. Light pruning throughout the growing season can help to shape and control its size. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Madagascar almond","description":"Terminalia neotaliala, the Madagascar almond tree, is a mid-sized tree in the leadwood tree family, Combretaceae. Regularly remove any yellow or damaged leaves to keep the plant healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fairy's-thimble","description":"Campanula cochleariifolia (also Campanula cochlearifolia), common name earleaf bellflower or fairy's-thimble, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Campanula of the family Campanulaceae, native to the Pyrenees, Alps, and Carpathian Mountains of Central Europe. It is a rhizomatous herbaceous perennial growing to 10 cm (4 in). Clumps of bright green leaves produce nodding pale blue bell flowers on wiry stalks.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Fairy's-thimble"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Campanula cochleariifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Mushrooms generally require indirect light or low light conditions to thrive. A dimly lit area or a location with filtered light, like under a shade cloth, is often ideal. This type of environment mimics their natural habitat on the forest floor. To provide appropriate lighting, consider using fluorescent or LED grow lights set on a timer to simulate a day/night cycle, replicating natural conditions without exposing them to too much direct light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning does not apply to Agrocybe putaminum in the traditional sense, as it is a mushroom and not a plant with leaves or branches. Instead, focus on harvesting the mushrooms correctly. When the caps of the mushrooms fully open, cut them at the base with a clean knife or scissors to prevent damage to the mycelium, allowing for continued and healthy fruiting. Regularly remove any decayed or malformed mushrooms to encourage better air circulation and prevent contamination."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mulch Fieldcap","description":"Agrocybe putaminum, commonly known as the mulch fieldcap, is a species of agaric fungus in the family Strophariaceae in the Agrocybe sororia complex. Fruitbodies of the fungus have a dull brownish-orange cap with a matte texture, a grooved stipe, and a bitter, mealy taste.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Mulch Fieldcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agrocybe putaminum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In dry spells and during hot summer months, increase the frequency of watering to ensure the tree receives adequate moisture. Mulching around the base helps retain soil moisture and keeps the roots cool. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely during the growing season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer pseudosieboldianum thrives in partial to full sun exposure. Ensure the tree is in a location where it gets at least a few hours of direct sunlight each day to support healthy growth and vibrant autumn foliage. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and the fall coloration could be less intense. Adjust the plant's sunlight exposure gradually to prevent stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer pseudosieboldianum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. The aim is to maintain the tree’s natural shape and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood. Prune away crossing branches to improve air circulation and allow light to penetrate the canopy, which can help prevent disease. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the tree and affect its overall health. For mature trees, light thinning can help maintain a more open structure. Regularly removing weak or congested branches will promote healthy growth and a more aesthetically pleasing form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Korean maple","description":"Acer pseudosieboldianum, the Korean maple or purplebloom maple, is a species of maple. It prefers soft, slightly acidic to neutral water, often found in nutrient-poor conditions. Maintaining clear, clean water is crucial to mimic its natural habitat and ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia australis prefers bright, indirect sunlight and typically thrives in full sun to partial shade. If growing indoors or in an aquarium, using artificial grow lights can supplement light requirements. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light supports photosynthesis which is vital for its growth and the health of its traps for capturing prey."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Utricularia australis, as it naturally regulates its growth. However, regular maintenance can involve removing dead or decaying plant material to prevent decomposition that could alter water quality. If the plant becomes overly dense, you can thin it out to encourage better water flow and light penetration, simply by cutting back excess growth. Ensure that you are not pruning too aggressively, as this plant relies on its foliage for capturing sunlight and nutrients. Routine checks can help in maintaining its aesthetic appeal and optimal health in controlled environments."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Yellow bladderwort","description":"Utricularia australis is a medium-sized, perennial species of aquatic bladderwort. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18293,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Entelea arborescens, commonly known as \"Whau,\" prefers consistently moist soil but is not tolerant of waterlogged conditions. During the growing season, it's vital to water the plant regularly to maintain soil moisture, especially during dry spells or hot weather. Reduce watering in winter when the plant's growth slows. It is adaptable but generally performs best with at least six hours of daily sunlight. If growing the plant indoors, place it in a bright spot, near a window that receives plenty of light. In more temperate climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. However, direct morning sunlight is usually beneficial, as it can assist in vigorous growth and development. Monitor the plant's response to the sunlight level, adjusting as necessary to avoid leaf burn or slowed growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Entelea arborescens primarily to maintain shape and remove any damaged or dead branches. Pruning should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This timing helps ensure the plant channels energy into developing robust new branches. Regular pruning may also encourage a more bushy and compact growth habit. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant and reducing the risk of transmitting diseases. Finally, be cautious not to over-prune, as the plant flowers on new wood, and excessive trimming could reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Whau","description":"Entelea arborescens or whau is a species of malvaceous tree endemic to New Zealand. E. arborescens is the only species in the genus Entelea. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18491,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio angulatus, also known as climbing groundsel, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered moderately. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the active growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently to keep the soil slightly moist, but be cautious not to soak it. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly as the plant's growth slows down. Always consider environmental factors like humidity and temperature when determining your watering schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio angulatus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates. Ideally, place the plant in a location where it can receive at least four to six hours of bright light, which promotes healthy growth and flowering. If you're growing it indoors, place it near a south-facing window with filtered sunlight. Avoid placing it in deep shade as it may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. For outdoor plants, a spot with morning sun and afternoon shade is optimal to prevent leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio angulatus is essential to maintain its shape and manage its growth as it can be quite vigorous. Prune the plant in the spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and to control its size. You can also remove up to a third of the plant's growth to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts above leaf nodes to encourage new growth. Regular pruning also helps prevent the plant from becoming too leggy and keeps it healthy and attractive during the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping groundsel","description":"Senecio angulatus also known as Creeping groundsel and sometimes as Cape ivy is a climbing succulent perennial from the family Asteraceae of the genus Senecio; a native of South Africa an alien in Australia, a problem weed in New Zealand, naturalized in North Africa, and cultivated elsewhere.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["creeping groundsel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Senecio angulatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18590,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyanus montanus, commonly known as perennial cornflower or mountain bluet, requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. However, ensure not to overwater as it can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. In winter, reduce watering frequency but do not let the plant dry out completely. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce abundant blooms. If placed in a spot with partial shade, ensure it receives adequate morning sunlight as it helps in strong growth and reduces susceptibilities to common diseases. Too much shade can result in spindly growth and fewer flowers. When planting, choose a location with full sun, especially in cooler climates, while providing afternoon shade in hotter zones to protect the plant from excessive heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cyanus montanus should be done to encourage healthy growth and maintain its shape. After the flowering period, usually in midsummer, deadhead the spent flowers to encourage a second bloom. Cut back the entire plant by about one-third to help rejuvenate it. In late autumn, prune back to ground level to prepare for winter. This not only keeps the plant tidy but also helps reduce the risk of pests and diseases overwintering in the old foliage. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Perennial Cornflower","description":"Centaurea montana (perennial cornflower, mountain cornflower, bachelor's button, montane knapweed or mountain bluet) is a species of Centaurea endemic to Europe. It is widespread and common in the more southerly mountain ranges of Europe, but is rarer in the north. It escapes from gardens readily, and has thereby become established in the British Isles, Scandinavia and North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Perennial Cornflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cyanus montanus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensuring the right balance of light will help maintain the plant’s vibrant color and healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Frullania dilatata is generally minimal, as liverworts do not have the typical stem and leaf structure of vascular plants. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18294,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agaricus bernardii, also known as the \"salt-loving mushroom,\" does not require traditional plant care instructions like watering as it is a fungus that typically grows in saline environments like coastal areas. However, if cultivated, ensure the growing medium is kept consistently moist but not overly saturated, mimicking its natural habitat conditions. Allow the substrate to dry slightly between watering to avoid fungal diseases and ensure aeration. Moisture management is key as mushrooms absorb water from the substrate rather than being watered directly like traditional plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mushrooms like Agaricus bernardii do not require direct sunlight, as they thrive in dim light conditions typically found in their natural habitat under substrates. Direct sunlight can dry out the growing media, so it's best to grow them in shaded or indirectly lit areas. If cultivated indoors, a low-light environment away from direct sun is ideal. Providing consistent humidity and temperature is more crucial than sunlight exposure for optimal growth. Aim for an environment that maintains a stable temperature with indirect lighting conditions to replicate its natural habitat for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike traditional plants, Agaricus bernardii and other mushrooms do not require pruning. However, proper management involves careful harvesting by gently twisting or cutting the mushroom at the base when the cap is fully developed but before it begins to flatten or upturn. This encourages further flushes and prevents decay on residual stubs. Handling the mushroom gently prevents damage to the mycelium network, allowing continued growth and production. Keeping the growing area clean and removing any spent or rotting mushrooms can help prevent contamination and promote healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Salt-loving Agaricus","description":"Agaricus bernardii, commonly called the salt-loving mushroom, is an agaric fungus in the family Agaricaceae. A short, squat mushroom, the thick stem is usually less than the diameter of the cap, which ranges from 5–15 cm (2.0–5.9 in). Found in Asia, Europe, North America, and New Zealand, it is a salt-tolerant species that grows in salt marshes, dunes, and coastal grassland. The fungus produces fruit bodies (mushrooms) with convex to flattened caps up to 15 cm (5.9 in) in diameter,...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Salt-loving Agaricus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Agaricus bernardii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Typically during the growing season (spring and summer), you may need to water every 2-3 weeks, whereas in the dormant season (fall and winter), watering can be reduced to once a month or even less. It is essential to adjust the frequency depending on the humidity and temperature of your environment, ensuring that the plant is not left in soggy conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heeria argentea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can be too intense and may cause scorching, while too little light can lead to leggy growth. The ideal location is by a window that receives filtered light or several hours of gentle morning sun. If indoors, placing the plant near an east or west-facing window is often suitable. Monitoring the plant's reaction to its placement is crucial, as signs of sunburn or etiolation (stretching) will indicate the need for adjustments in lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heeria argentea is generally minimal, focusing mainly on maintaining shape and removing any dead or unhealthy growth. Occasionally, trim off any wilted or dried leaves to keep the plant looking tidy and to prevent any potential pest issues. If the plant becomes leggy, which can occur if it's not receiving enough light, prune it back to encourage more compact growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and the risk of infection. Pruning is best done during the growing season as the plant will heal faster."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rockwood","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silver"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Rockwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Heeria argentea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19693,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronica speciosa, commonly known as Hebe, thrives in well-drained soil and requires regular watering, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Ensure the soil is consistently moist, but not waterlogged, as soggy roots can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply, allowing excess water to drain completely. In the cooler months, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows. Always check the soil moisture before watering by inserting your finger about an inch deep; if it feels dry, it’s time to water. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases on foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronica speciosa flourishes with ample sunlight and should be placed in a location where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. Ideally, position it in a spot that benefits from full morning sun with some protection from the harsh afternoon rays, especially in hot climates. In hotter regions, a site with dappled afternoon shade helps prevent foliage scorch, whereas in cooler areas, full sun is generally beneficial. Good light exposure ensures robust blooms and maintains the vibrancy of the foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To keep Veronica speciosa looking its best, prune lightly after it finishes flowering to remove spent blooms and encourage bushier growth. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to cut back any dead or diseased stems, and shape the plant by trimming long, leggy branches. This promotes a compact form and increases airflow, which can prevent disease. Avoid heavy pruning in late autumn as it can stimulate new growth that might not withstand winter. Maintaining a tidy shape encourages more vibrant flowering in the upcoming season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"New Zealand hebe","description":"Hebe speciosa is a species of flowering plant in the plantain family known by the common names New Zealand hebe, showy hebe, showy-speedwell, and the Maori names Titirangi and Napuka. It is native to New Zealand but it can be found in other parts of the world where it is grown as an ornamental for its showy flowers. This hebe is a shrub reaching heights between one and two meters. Its evergreen leaves are dark green,...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["New Zealand hebe"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Veronica speciosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18996,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melica uniflora, commonly known as wood melick, prefers moderately moist soil conditions. It is essential to maintain a consistent moisture level, especially during dry spells, to ensure healthy growth. However, avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. Typically, watering once a week should suffice, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. During rainy seasons or in areas with high humidity, additional watering may not be necessary. Ensure good drainage in the planting area to prevent waterlogging, which could be detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melica uniflora thrives in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. It can tolerate some sunlight, particularly in cooler morning hours, but should be protected from harsh midday or afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves, leading to wilting or burn. Dappled sunlight, such as that filtered through tree canopies, is ideal for this plant. If planted in full sun, ensure that the soil is kept moist, as the increased light may quicken the drying of the soil, requiring more frequent watering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melica uniflora involves removing any dead or damaged stems to encourage new growth. You can cut back the plant in late winter or early spring to tidy up its appearance and stimulate fresh growth as it comes out of dormancy. Regularly check for dead leaves and stems during the growing season, trimming them away as needed. Avoid cutting back more than one-third of the plant's overall foliage at any one time, as this could stress the plant. Proper pruning will help maintain its manageable size and natural grace."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wood Melick","description":"Melica uniflora, commonly known as wood melick, is a species of grass in the family Poaceae that is native to much of Europe, and to parts of South West Asia and North Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Wood Melick"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Stem rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Melica uniflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19389,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron menziesii, like many rhododendrons, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It is important not to let the soil dry out completely, especially during the growing season from spring to fall. Water the plant deeply every week, allowing the top of the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching around the base can help maintain moisture levels and reduce weeds. Be cautious not to overwater, as waterlogged soil can also be detrimental. During winter, reduce watering, but do ensure that the soil does not become fully dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron menziesii prefers partial shade, especially in hotter climates, as too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves and stress the plant. Ideally, it should receive morning sun with afternoon shade or dappled sunlight throughout the day. In cooler climates, it can tolerate brighter conditions. Ensure that the planting location provides some shelter from harsh midday sun and strong winds, which can dehydrate the plant. If grown in too much shade, flowering may be reduced. Carefully choose a location that balances light exposure to optimize growth and bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron menziesii is typically done after flowering in late spring or early summer. This timing prevents the accidental removal of next year's buds, as rhododendrons set their flower buds on old wood. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood with clean, sharp pruning shears. Lightly thin the shrub to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Older plants can benefit from rejuvenation pruning by cutting back some of the older branches to a lower node, encouraging new growth. Avoid heavy pruning that significantly reduces plant size, as rhododendrons do not respond well to hard pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mock azalea","description":"Rhododendron menziesii, also classified as Menziesia ferruginea, is a species of flowering plant in the heath family known by several common names, including rusty menziesia, ock azalea, false huckleberry, and mock azalea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["mock azalea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron menziesii"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18494,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus cembra, commonly known as the Swiss stone pine, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once established. Ensure the soil never becomes soggy, as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings, but be cautious not to let it dry out completely, as young plants are more susceptible to drought stress."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus cembra thrives best in full sun conditions, ideally receiving at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. However, it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates or during the afternoon when the sun is at its strongest. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. When removing branches, cut them back to the main trunk or a healthy lateral branch to avoid leaving stubs. It is important to avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the tree and reduce its aesthetic value. Light pruning to maintain shape or manage size can be beneficial, but always ensure you maintain the tree's natural form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swiss pine","description":"Pinus cembra, also known as Swiss pine, Swiss stone pine or Arolla pine or Austrian stone pine or just Stone pine, is a species of pine tree that grows in the Alps and Carpathian Mountains of central Europe, in Poland (Tatra Mountains), Switzerland, France, Italy, Austria, Germany, Slovenia, Slovakia (Tatra Mountains), Ukraine and Romania. It typically grows at 1,200 metres (3,900 ft) to 2,300 metres (7,500 ft) altitude. However, to mitigate its effects on infected plants, ensure plants are watered at the base to avoid wetting the foliage, which can exacerbate rust fungal diseases. Additionally, remove and destroy affected leaves to further control moisture around the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"While Puccinia malvacearum is a rust fungus and not a plant, sunlight can play a role in managing its spread on host plants. Infected plants, such as hollyhocks, benefit from ample sunlight, which helps keep the foliage dry and less susceptible to fungal diseases. Full sun exposure can help plants grow vigorously, thereby maintaining their health and resilience against infections. Additionally, adequate sunlight reduces the moisture level on leaves due to rapid drying, thus reducing the chances of rust development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not directly applicable to Puccinia malvacearum, as it is a fungus affecting plants. However, pruning the host plant to remove affected leaves and promote better air circulation can help mitigate the spread of rust. Cut back any severely infected parts of the plant and dispose of them properly, away from the garden. Regularly inspect plants and prune diseased foliage as soon as it appears, which can help control and limit the development and outbreak of rust fungi in your garden."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Hollyhock Rust","description":"Puccinia malvacearum, also known as hollyhock or mallow rust, is a species within the Puccinia genus known for attacking members of the Malvaceae family. It's essential to avoid waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to fungal infections or other issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lactarius argillaceifolius, like many mushrooms, does not require direct sunlight. Instead, it thrives in shaded and humid conditions typical of forest floors. When cultivating, place it in a dimly lit area that simulates these natural environments, ensuring that it does not receive direct sunlight, which can dry out the substrate and harm the mushrooms. Indirect light, such as that from a shaded window or fluorescent lighting, is typically sufficient to support its growth. Proper light management will help promote healthy and optimal fruiting of the mushrooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to mushrooms like Lactarius argillaceifolius in the same way it is to plants. Mushrooms do not have structures like leaves, branches, or stems that require pruning. However, during the fruiting period, removing mature or over-mature mushrooms by cutting or gently twisting helps to prevent rot and makes space for new fruiting bodies. This also maintains cleanliness in the growing area, reducing the risk of pests and diseases. Always handle the mushrooms gently to avoid disturbing the mycelium or other mushrooms growing nearby."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Clay-gilled Milkcap","description":"Lactarius argillaceifolius is a species of fungus in the Russulaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18998,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron mucronulatum prefers well-drained, consistently moist soil. It is important to water the plant thoroughly during the growing season, especially in periods of dry weather, but care should be taken to avoid waterlogging. The soil should be kept evenly moist but never soggy. During the winter months, watering should be reduced but not completely stopped, as the plant still requires moisture. It's beneficial to use mulch to retain soil moisture and maintain even soil temperatures."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron mucronulatum thrives in partial sun conditions. It prefers a spot where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade to protect it from the harshness of direct midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. In cooler climates, it can tolerate more sun, but in hotter regions, it should be protected from intense sunlight. Finding a balance is key to encouraging prolific blooming without stressing the plant. Dappled sunlight under a canopy or a location with filtered light is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Rhododendron mucronulatum should be done after they finish flowering, typically in late spring to early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. To shape the plant or control its size, pruning can include trimming back branches just above a bud or leaf node. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can reduce flowering for the next season. Minimal pruning usually suffices to allow the plant to retain its natural form while encouraging bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Korean rhododendron","description":"Rhododendron mucronulatum, known as Korean rhododendron or Korean rosebay, is a rhododendron species native to Korea, Mongolia, and Russia. It is a shrub that grows to 1–2 m in height, with leaves that are elliptic or elliptic-lanceolate, 3–7 by 1–3.5 cm in size. Flowers are reddish purple.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Korea","Russia","China"],"other_name":["Korean rhododendron"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron mucronulatum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19201,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Plantago asiatica prefers moderately moist soil but is tolerant of occasional dry spells. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Avoid waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. In its active growing phase during Spring and Summer, you might need to water more frequently, once or twice a week, depending on the climate. Reduce watering during the Fall and Winter months when the plant is dormant, allowing the soil to dry out more between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plantago asiatica thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal growth. In regions with intense summer sunlight, it's advisable to provide some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorching. Ensure that it is not placed in deep shade as insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and poor health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Plantago asiatica involves removing any dead or yellowing leaves that may occur to keep the plant healthy and tidy. You can trim back the flowering spikes after they have bloomed to prevent self-seeding and to encourage the plant to focus on leaf growth. In early spring, remove any dead foliage to make way for new growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to make clean cuts, and always prune back to a healthy part of the plant to encourage regrowth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Asian plantain","description":"Plantago asiatica, is a self-fertile, perennial flowering plant of genus Plantago. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19695,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aphyllon purpureum, commonly known as broomrape, requires minimal watering as it is a parasitic plant that does not rely on soil moisture in the traditional sense. Instead, it attaches to the roots of a host plant and derives its nutrients and water from the host. Therefore, focus on maintaining appropriate moisture levels for the host plant rather than the broomrape itself, ensuring the host plant is neither overly dry nor waterlogged to support a healthy environment for the parasitic plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aphyllon purpureum grows well in conditions that suit its host plant, and typically thrives in well-lit conditions since it is not directly reliant on sunlight for photosynthesis, as it is non-photosynthetic. It can tolerate full to partial sunlight depending on the host plant's preferences. Ensure that the host plant receives its required sunlight conditions to maintain overall plant health and the parasitic relationship, observing the host's leaf color and growth for signs of stress due to excessive or insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aphyllon purpureum is not typically required, as it is a small, parasitic plant that often relies on its host for structure and support. However, if the broomrape becomes too dense or starts to negatively impact the host plant's growth by over-parasitizing, you may carefully trim some of the stems. Always use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to prevent any potential disease transmission and ensure that trimming does not damage the host plant's structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"oneflower broomrape","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["oneflower broomrape"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aphyllon purpureum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18894,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spinellus fusiger, more commonly involved with fungi, does not require traditional plant care such as watering. This species is a type of parasitic fungus that infests the bodies of other fungi, primarily mushrooms, absorbing nutrients directly from its host. No watering care is necessary; instead, its growth depends on the presence of suitable host fungi found in their natural moist environments. In controlled environments, maintaining high humidity may facilitate its growth on host fungi but direct watering is unnecessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spinellus fusiger thrives in conditions that favor its mushroom hosts, which are typically found in damp, shaded, or semi-shaded areas such as forest floors. Direct sunlight is not beneficial and may even inhibit its growth. Instead, this fungus prefers low light conditions; replicating these can help sustain its lifecycle. In artificial settings, indirect light or low-intensity artificial light sources can mimic the dappled sunlight of its natural habitat, supporting the fungal hosts and consequently the growth of Spinellus fusiger."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a parasitic fungus rather than a plant, Spinellus fusiger does not require pruning in the conventional sense. Pruning typically involves removing parts to encourage growth, aesthetics, or health in plants, but for fungi like Spinellus fusiger, management involves controlling their spread. Ensuring suitable environmental conditions and removing unwanted fungal hosts can help manage their prevalence. In research or natural study settings, controlling the host population will assist in managing Spinellus fusiger populations effectively."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bonnet mold","description":"Spinellus fusiger, commonly known as the bonnet mold, is a species of fungus in the Zygomycota phylum. It is a pin mold that is characterized by erect sporangiophores (specialized hyphae that bear a sporangium) that are simple in structure, brown or yellowish-brown in color, and with branched aerial filaments that bear the zygospores. It grows as a parasitic mold on mushrooms, including several species from the genera Mycena, including M. haematopus, M. pura, M. epipterygia, M. leptocephala, and various Collybia...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["bonnet mold"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Spinellus fusiger"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19391,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Neoboletus luridiformis, commonly known as the scarletina bolete, is a mushroom that typically requires a moist environment to thrive. In its natural habitat, it grows in symbiosis with trees and benefits from the moisture present in forest soils. When cultivating these mushrooms, ensure that the substrate remains sufficiently moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to rot and other issues. It’s important to maintain a balance by allowing the substrate to dry out slightly between watering to replicate its natural conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Neoboletus luridiformis thrives in dappled sunlight conditions similar to its natural woodland habitat. It prefers areas with filtered light, as direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and harm the growth conditions. If growing this mushroom indoors, use a shaded location or provide artificial lighting that mimics natural, indirect sunlight. Too much light can impede the humidity critical for its growth, whereas too little light can slow its development. Aim for a balanced lighting environment to ensure optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Neoboletus luridiformis, as it is a mushroom and not a plant requiring traditional pruning. Instead, focus on harvesting practices. When the mushroom cap reaches about 5-10 cm in diameter and the stipe is solid and firm, it can be gently twisted and pulled from the substrate. This helps in spreading spores for natural propagation while ensuring the surrounding environment remains undisturbed for future growth. Thinning out overcrowded canes will increase air circulation, reducing the risk of disease and promoting better fruit production if it's a fruit-bearing variety. For better yield, remove old canes that have already fruited; this encourages the development of new canes which will bear the next season's fruit. Sufficient sunlight helps in maintaining the plant's vibrant foliage and compact shape, while inadequate light may result in leggy growth and reduced flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Olearia avicenniifolia is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. If attempting to cultivate or study it, ensure that it mimics its native conditions by avoiding overly sunny and dry areas, and emulate the filtered light typical under forest canopies."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Amanita xanthocephala, as it is a type of mushroom and not a plant with stems or leaves that require trimming. Mushrooms generally do not require nor benefit from pruning. Instead, focus should be placed on providing it with suitable growing conditions and avoiding disruption of its natural environment. Care should be taken when harvesting to ensure that the base and surrounding mycelium are left intact to promote further growth."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Vermilion Amanita","description":"The vermilion grisette, also known as pretty grisette or vermilion Amanita (Amanita xanthocephala) is a colourful mushroom of the genus Amanita. Therefore, ensure it receives at least four to six hours of bright, indirect light daily for optimal health and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalanchoe rotundifolia is beneficial to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. It is best to prune in the spring after the plant has finished flowering. Remove any dead or wilted flowers by pinching them off at the base. Instead, it typically grows in humid and moist environments where it can absorb moisture from the air and surrounding substrate. If cultivating this fungus, maintaining a high humidity environment is crucial, usually achieved through misting or using a humidifier in an enclosed space to mimic its natural conditions. Ensure the substrate is damp but not waterlogged, as standing water can lead to rot or other fungal infections."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnopilus thiersii does not require direct sunlight, as it naturally grows on forest decaying wood, primarily relying on ambient light to guide its growth and sporulation. It thrives in shaded, indirect light conditions, ensuring the environment remains humid and moist due to the lack of evaporation caused by direct sunlight. When cultivating, place it in a well-lit but indirect light area to simulate its natural habitats for optimal growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to fungi like Gymnopilus thiersii as it is for plants. However, if you are cultivating it and need to manage growth for study or harvest purposes, you can carefully harvest mature specimens using clean tools to avoid contamination. Always leave some of the mycelium and substrate intact to encourage continued growth and avoid damaging the mycelial network, allowing future flushes of mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Gymnopilus thiersii is a species of mushroom in the Cortinariaceae family. It is nearly identical to Gymnopilus luteofolius, but this species differs in having different context colors and dextrinoid spores. The type location for Gymnopilus thiersii is Wunderlich Park in San Mateo County, California. This species contains the hallucinogenic drugs psilocybin and psilocin, and stains blue-green where damaged.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Gymnopilus thiersii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18895,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Glandora prostrata prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In hotter weather or when the plant is grown in a pot, it may require more frequent watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. As a drought-tolerant plant, it can withstand short periods of dry conditions, but regular watering promotes optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glandora prostrata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal flowering and growth. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. Full sun promotes dense growth and vibrant blooms, whereas too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown indoors, a south-facing window with plenty of direct sunlight would be ideal. Be mindful of intense midday sun, which can sometimes cause leaf scorching, especially in hotter regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glandora prostrata helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Trim back any dead or damaged branches in early spring before new growth begins. Lightly trimming the plant after its flowering period in late spring or early summer will stimulate further blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. Removing spent flowers can help extend the bloom period and prevent seed formation, which conserves the plant's energy. Regular pruning also prevents the plant from becoming too woody and encourages bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping gromwell","description":"Glandora prostrata, the shrubby gromwell, creeping gromwell or purple gromwell (names it shares with Lithospermum purpurocaeruleum and Glandora diffusa), is a species of Glandora native to Portugal, Spain and France. Its cultivars 'Grace Ward' and 'Heavenly Blue' have gained the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southern Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["creeping gromwell"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Glandora prostrata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18497,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ceroxylon quindiuense, also known as the Quindío wax palm, prefers consistently moist soil but is sensitive to overwatering. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil stays slightly damp, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. However, avoid waterlogging as the roots can rot in overly wet conditions. During the winter months, reduce watering but never let the soil dry out completely. It's important to ensure proper drainage in the potting mix to maintain the right moisture balance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Quindío wax palm thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It prefers locations where it can receive filtered light, avoiding intense, direct sun which can damage the leaves. If grown indoors, place it in a well-lit room but away from harsh, direct sunlight, perhaps near an east or north-facing window. Outdoors, it flourishes in partially shaded areas that provide protection from the midday sun. Ensuring the plant has adequate light helps promote healthy growth and maintain vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ceroxylon quindiuense is minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged fronds. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut off dead fronds close to the base. Avoid cutting healthy, green fronds as this can stress the plant and hinder its growth. Regularly check for old fronds that naturally brown and die off, removing them to maintain the plant's appearance and reduce potential pest infestations. Pruning should ideally be done in the growing season when the plant is most resilient."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Quindio Wax Palm","description":"Ceroxylon quindiuense is a palm native to the humid montane forests of the Andes in Colombia and northern Peru.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Colombia"],"other_name":["Quindio Wax Palm"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Ceroxylon quindiuense"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
