{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18700,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gentianella bellidifolia, like many alpine plants, requires careful watering to mimic the moist, well-drained conditions of its natural habitat. Water the plant regularly but ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent water saturation, which can lead to root rot. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the active growing season, moderate watering is sufficient, but in the winter months, reduce watering to prevent too much moisture, especially if the plant is in a less sunny, cooler environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentianella bellidifolia thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate short periods of direct light, especially during the morning or late afternoon. In its natural alpine habitat, it is accustomed to cooler temperatures and moderate light levels. Place the plant in a location that receives plenty of light but avoids the harsh midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, a bright windowsill with filtered light is ideal. During winter, consider supplementing with a grow light if natural light is insufficient to maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gentianella bellidifolia is minimal but essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Trim back any dead or yellowing leaves or stems using sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears. This can help direct the plant's energy towards new growth. However, heavy pruning is not generally necessary for this species. Removing spent flowers can also help the plant to focus on producing new blooms. Always prune just above a leaf node or junction to promote regrowth and avoid cutting too far back into the woody stems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common New Zealand Gentian","description":"Gentianella bellidifolia is a species of the genus Gentianella that is native to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Common New Zealand Gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Gentianella bellidifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18803,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sophora molloyi prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered. Water the plant thoroughly but allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. Generally, it's best to water once a week during the growing season and reduce to once every two weeks during the dormant winter months. Make sure the pot has adequate drainage to prevent water from sitting at the roots, which can cause rot. Adjust the frequency based on your local climate and indoor conditions, as too much moisture can be detrimental."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sophora molloyi thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. When planted in a shadier spot, it might grow more leggy and produce fewer blooms. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive abundant light. During the hotter summer months, some light afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Regularly rotating the plant helps ensure even light exposure and balanced growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sophora molloyi should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote better airflow and light penetration. It's also helpful to trim back any crossing branches and to shape the plant to encourage a bushier growth habit. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts and minimize damage to the plant. Light pruning can be done throughout the growing season to remove any unwanted growth or to maintain the desired shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cook Strait Kowhai","description":"Cook Strait kōwhai (Sophora molloyi), also known as Molloy's kōwhai or Stephen's Island kōwhai, is one of 8 species of kōwhai native to New Zealand, and grows naturally around the Cook Strait region. It was first described as a species in 2001 and named after Dr. Brian Molloy of Landcare Research, who was a researcher and scientist there for more than 30 years.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Cook Strait Kowhai"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Sophora molloyi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19293,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senegalia mellifera, also known as Blackthorn or Thorn Tree, is a drought-tolerant plant native to arid and semi-arid regions. It requires infrequent watering once established, typically every 3-4 weeks during dry periods. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. It thrives in well-drained soil and can tolerate periods of drought once its root system is mature. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings. In its early stages, it may benefit from more frequent watering to help establish the roots, especially in sandy or quick-draining soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senegalia mellifera thrives in full sun environments, requiring a minimum of 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. It is well adapted to hot and arid climates and can withstand extreme temperatures and prolonged sun exposure. If growing indoors or in a shaded area, ensure it receives as much bright light as possible, as inadequate sunlight can inhibit growth and affect its flowering. Placing it in a south-facing position outdoors or near a sunny window indoors will help it maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senegalia mellifera is not strictly necessary but can help maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and prevent pest infestations. Light shaping can control the size and spread of the plant, but avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant. Remove any suckers that may emerge from the base to maintain the desired form, especially if the plant is used ornamentally in landscapes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black thorn","description":"Senegalia mellifera is a common thorn tree in Africa. The name mellifera refers to its sweet-smelling blossoms and honey. Its lumber turns pitch black when oiled. Common names of the tree include Blackthorn and Swarthaak (Afrikaans). It is listed as being not threatened.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa","Middle East"],"other_name":["Black thorn"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Senegalia mellifera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18401,"attracts":["Fish","Invertebrates"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zostera muelleri, commonly known as eelgrass, is an aquatic plant that thrives in marine environments. In a home aquarium, it does not require typical \"watering\" like terrestrial plants. Instead, the focus is on maintaining optimal water conditions. Ensure the water salinity mimics its natural estuarine habitat, typically ranging from brackish to full seawater salinity levels (around 20-35 ppt). Regularly replacing a portion of the tank's water helps sustain nutrient balance vital for its growth. Monitoring the water quality, including pH, temperature, and nutrient levels, is crucial for the health of Zostera muelleri."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zostera muelleri prefers full sun to partial shade conditions in its natural habitat. For aquariums, implementing strong artificial lighting is necessary to mimic such sunny conditions—using full-spectrum aquarium lights that can penetrate water effectively and support photosynthesis is ideal. Ensure the light source provides between 8 to 12 hours of illumination each day to replicate natural cycles. Balancing light intensity and duration helps prevent algae overgrowth, which can otherwise swamp the plant and limit its access to light, hindering its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zostera muelleri involves managing its growth to prevent it from taking over the space in which it's planted. Carefully trim the seagrass with clean scissors or aquascaping shears to remove dead or decaying parts. This should be done periodically to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's health. Since this plant spreads via rhizomes, if you're maintaining it in an aquarium, regular pruning helps manage its propagation. Remove any algae growth manually, as it can compete for nutrients and light, hampering the growth of your seagrass."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dwarf Grass-wrack","description":"Zostera muelleri is a southern hemisphere temperate species of seagrass native to the seacoasts of South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. and New Zealand. It is important to ensure that the soil drains well and does not retain water, as Proteas are susceptible to root rot in waterlogged soils. During the dry season, water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During rainy seasons or cooler weather, watering should be reduced significantly. When watering, aim to wet the root zone thoroughly rather than doing surface-level watering. Placing the plant in an area where it receives ample sun exposure will ensure vibrant blooms and healthy growth. If grown indoors or in partially shaded areas, the plant may experience stunted growth or reduced flowering. Therefore, it is crucial to select a planting site or indoor position that maximizes light availability. In extreme heat zones, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching, but generally, more sunlight is preferable for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Protea longifolia helps maintain its shape and encourages flowering. It’s best to prune after flowering, typically in late winter. Use clean, sharp tools to cut back spent flower heads and reshape the plant if needed. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this can reduce future blooming. Focus on removing dead or damaged stems, crossing branches, and thinning out crowded areas to improve air circulation within the plant. Regular deadheading will also promote longer flowering periods and improve overall plant health. Always sterilize your pruning tools before use to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Long-leaf Sugarbush","description":"Protea longifolia, commonly known as the long-leaf sugarbush, is a shrub of the Proteaceae family that is native to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Long-leaf Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Protea longifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In Britain it has declined in numbers because of modern farming techniques and draining of wet-lands and is no longer common. However, ensure to rotate the plant occasionally to maintain even growth. Too little light may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering, while too much intense sunlight can cause leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium brevicaule involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to promote healthy growth. This should be done regularly throughout the growing season. Use clean, sharp scissors or garden shears for precise cuts. Pinch back the stems to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also help extend the blooming period. It's best to prune in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid stressing the plant during the hottest parts of the day. Avoid overwatering to prevent stagnant water, which can lead to mold or algae growth. Allow the top layer to slightly dry between watering schedules, but ensure the underlying substrate remains moist. Rainwater or distilled water is preferable to avoid mineral buildup."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ptychomnion aciculare prefers low to moderate light conditions, mimicking the dappled sunlight of its natural forest floor habitat. It thrives in indirect light, as direct sunlight can cause it to dry out and become stressed. Indoors, place the moss where it receives filtered sunlight or in a shaded area. If outdoors, ensure it is under partial shade, such as a canopy of trees. If artificial lighting is used, ensure the light is not too intense or hot. Maintaining an appropriate light level is crucial for preventing evaporation and ensuring lush growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ptychomnion aciculare is generally minimal, as mosses are slow-growing and do not require frequent trimming. However, to maintain its appearance and promote healthy growth, occasionally remove any dead or discolored parts. This can be done gently by hand or with sterilized scissors to prevent disease spread. Trimming may also help maintain desired shape and density if the moss is part of a decorative feature. Regular grooming helps reduce competition for nutrients and light, enhancing its verdant appearance. Do this sparingly to avoid unnecessary stress on the moss."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pipe-cleaner moss","description":"Ptychomnion aciculare is a species of moss found in Australia, New Zealand, New Caledonia, Samoa, Juan Fernandez Islands and Chile.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["pipe-cleaner moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ptychomnion aciculare"],"soil":["Watery","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ideally, check daily and adjust watering according to the environmental humidity levels, paying close attention to the substrate's wetness."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"While specific light conditions for Paralepista flaccida in cultivation can vary, these wild mushrooms typically grow on the forest floor and are adapted to dappled or partial shade. They thrive in cool, shaded conditions with filtered or diffused light. Ensure that they receive moderate light, similar to what one might find in a shaded woodland area, which is crucial for their successful growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally not applicable for mushrooms like Paralepista flaccida, as they are fungi rather than traditional plants. However, you can maintain healthy growth by regularly harvesting mature mushrooms, which encourages continued fruiting. Use a sharp knife to cut the mushrooms at their base to avoid damaging the mycelium. Also, remove any decayed or overly mature mushrooms to prevent them from attracting pests or diseases that could spread to healthier specimens. Regularly inspect your mushrooms to ensure that any necessary cleaning or removal is performed promptly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tawny funnel cap","description":"Paralepista flaccida (also called Clitocybe flaccida, Clitocybe inversa, Lepista flaccida and Lepista inversa, or in English \"Tawny Funnel Cap\") is a species of mushroom found across the Northern Hemisphere. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19493,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eupatorium formosanum, like many perennials, prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells or hot summer months, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. Adjust your watering schedule based on rainfall and seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eupatorium formosanum thrives best in full sun to light shade, with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering and growth. When planted in full sun, ensure the soil remains moist to prevent dehydration. However, if the plant is in a location with intense, direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, partial shade during the hottest part of the day can protect it from scorching. If planted in too much shade, the plant may become leggy with fewer flowers. It's crucial to balance sunlight exposure with proper watering for a healthy plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eupatorium formosanum is essential to maintain its shape and encourage robust growth. In early spring, before new growth appears, cut back any dead or damaged stems to the base to encourage fresh growth. Throughout the growing season, pinch back the tips of young shoots to promote bushier growth and more flower production. After the plant has finished flowering, you can also deadhead spent blooms to improve its appearance and potentially encourage a second bloom. In late fall, cut the stems back to about 6 inches above the ground to prepare the plant for winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ground qalanis","description":"Eupatorium formosanum is a plant species in family Asteraceae. It is found in Taiwan and the Ryukyu Islands (Japan). It is a perennial herb growing about 2 m (7 ft) tall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan","East Asia"],"other_name":["ground qalanis"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Eupatorium formosanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19394,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Watsonia tabularis prefers moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist during the growing season, which often aligns with spring and summer. However, overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to ensure the roots do not stay waterlogged. During its dormant period in late fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out more thoroughly, as the plant will need less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Watsonia tabularis thrives in full sunlight exposure for at least six hours a day. It is native to regions with plenty of sun, and thus performs best in bright, direct sunlight. If grown in partial shade, it may not flower as profusely and could become leggy. For optimal growth and blooming, place the plant in a location where it receives direct sunlight during the morning and early afternoon. However, in exceedingly hot climates, providing some light afternoon shade can help protect it from intense sunlight stress. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Watsonia tabularis mainly involves cutting back the old flowering stems and dead foliage. Once the flowers fade and the flowering stems begin to die, they can be cut back to the base to encourage healthy growth. This usually happens in late summer to early fall. It's also beneficial to remove any dead or diseased leaves to promote better air circulation and prevent fungal issues. Avoid pruning in the dormancy period, as the plant is not actively growing and does not require shaping or maintenance then."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Table Mountain Watsonia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Table Mountain Watsonia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Watsonia tabularis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18597,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus margaretiae, commonly known as the sand post oak, is a drought-tolerant species that typically does not require frequent watering once established. It prefers well-drained sandy or rocky soils, and overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. During the tree's first few years, provide deep watering once a week during dry spells. After establishment, natural rainfall is generally sufficient. However, in prolonged drought periods, occasional deep watering may be beneficial. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering to mimic its natural conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus margaretiae thrives in full sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, plant it in a location that receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Full sun exposure encourages a robust structure and denser foliage, enhancing the tree's overall health and appearance. While it can grow in partial shade, its growth rate may slow, and it might become less compact and more open. Ensuring the tree gets adequate sunlight is crucial for its development and resilience against pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus margaretiae should be done to promote a strong structure and remove any damaged or diseased branches. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on thinning the canopy to allow for better air circulation and sunlight penetration. Maintain a single central leader and remove any crossing or rubbing branches. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree. Regular inspections throughout the year can help identify and manage any issues early on, ensuring the tree remains healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sand post oak","description":"Quercus margarettae, the sand post oak or dwarf post oak, is a North American species of oak in the beech family. It is native to the southeastern and south-central United States from Virginia to Florida and west as far as Texas and Oklahoma. There are historical reports of the species growing in New York State, but it has not been seen there in years.","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["sand post oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Gall insects","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Quercus margaretiae"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19204,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Passiflora incarnata × cincinnata should be watered regularly to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. During the growing season, it's essential to ensure the plant receives enough water, typically every few days, especially in hot weather. It’s important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In the winter, when the plant's growth slows, you can reduce watering frequency. Always use well-draining soil to avoid water accumulation, and make sure the pot or garden bed has proper drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This hybrid passionflower thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure optimal flowering and growth. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. If grown indoors or in a greenhouse, placing it near a bright, south-facing window will simulate these conditions. However, the plant can also tolerate some light shade, but reduced sunlight may lead to fewer flowers. Ensure any indoor light sources mimic natural sunlight's intensity as much as possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Passiflora incarnata × cincinnata is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Trim back any dead, damaged, or unruly stems to keep the plant tidy and manage its size. Regular pruning helps promote better airflow and prevents diseases. If the plant becomes too dense, thin out some of the older growth to encourage new shoots. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and minimize damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Passiflora 'Incense'","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["USA"],"other_name":["Passiflora 'Incense'"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Passiflora incarnata × cincinnata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19096,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aesculus × carnea prefers consistent moisture, especially in its early growth stages. It thrives in well-drained soil, so avoid letting the soil become waterlogged. During dry spells or extended periods without rain, supplemental watering is beneficial to maintain healthy growth. It’s important to water it deeply but infrequently, encouraging the roots to grow deeper and become more drought-tolerant. Check the soil’s moisture level periodically, and ensure that it remains slightly damp but not soggy. Be cautious of overwatering, as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aesculus × carnea thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its robust growth and beautiful flowering. While it can tolerate some shade, too much may result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat. When planting, choose a site that offers optimal sunlight exposure during the day, allowing the plant to develop a strong structure and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aesculus × carnea is usually done to manage its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The ideal time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any crossing or crowded branches to ensure ample air circulation within the canopy. This plant generally requires minimal pruning, but any necessary cuts should be made with clean, sharp tools to minimize stress and potential disease transmission. Regularly inspect the tree and prune away any suckers or lower branches that may interfere with pedestrian or vehicle traffic."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red horse-chestnut","description":"Aesculus × carnea, or red horse-chestnut, is an artificial hybrid between A. pavia (red buckeye) and A. hippocastanum (horse-chestnut). The origin of the tree is not known, but it probably first appeared in Germany before 1820. The hybrid is a medium-size tree to 20–25 m tall, intermediate between the parent species in most respects, but inheriting the red flower color from A. pavia. It is a popular tree in large gardens and parks.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Red horse-chestnut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf blotch","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Aesculus × carnea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18897,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Watering needs for Rhus integrifolia × ovata, commonly known as sugar bush or lemonade berry, should be focused on allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. This plant is drought-tolerant once established, so it requires minimal watering. During the first year after planting, water the shrub deeply every 7-10 days to help it establish a robust root system. After the first year, reduce the frequency to once every few weeks, depending on your local climate and weather conditions. Avoid over-watering, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot and other issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhus integrifolia × ovata thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. Planting in a bright, sunny location ensures vibrant foliage and optimal flowering. While it can handle some shade, too much can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If you are in a particularly hot climate, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. This plant is adaptable and can succeed in various light conditions, but full sun is ideal for lush growth and a bountiful berry production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Rhus integrifolia × ovata is generally minimal. However, you should perform some maintenance pruning to keep its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Insufficient sunlight can lead to poor flowering and leggy growth. Adjust the plant’s position if you notice it reaching or stretching toward the light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Clerodendrum quadriloculare is usually carried out to maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. The best time to prune is during the late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or diseased branches, and trim back any overly long shoots that disrupt the desired shape. Always use clean and sharp tools to prevent the spread of plant diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Starburst Bush","description":"Clerodendrum quadriloculare is a species of flowering plant native to New Guinea and the Philippines. It is endemic to Taiwan, but widely cultivated in East Asia and sometimes in other tropical regions as well. It's also advisable to cut back any overly vigorous stalks early in the growing season to manage growth form. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts, ensuring clean wounds and reducing the risk of disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wood Ragwort","description":"Senecio ovatus, common name wood ragwort, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Wood Ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Senecio ovatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant thoroughly every two to three weeks, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In winter, significantly reduce watering, as the plant goes dormant and can be prone to root rot in cold, wet conditions. Ensure the pot or ground has excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging, which this succulent is particularly sensitive to."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aloidendron dichotomum thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is accustomed to hot, arid environments and can tolerate very bright light conditions, making it ideal for open, sunny locations in a garden or near a south-facing window indoors. Insufficient sunlight can lead to weak, leggy growth, so if grown indoors, place the plant in the brightest spot available. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may prevent scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aloidendron dichotomum is generally minimal. Remove only dead or damaged leaves close to their base, using clean, sharp scissors or garden shears to avoid transmitting diseases. It's important to prune cautiously because over-pruning can stress the plant. Ensure any pruned areas are dry to reduce the risk of infection, particularly during the rainy season. Only prune in late winter or early spring before the plant enters its active growth phase, as this timing helps the plant recover more quickly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Quiver Tree","description":"Aloidendron dichotomum, formerly Aloe dichotoma, the quiver tree or kokerboom, is a tall, branching species of succulent plant, indigenous to Southern Africa, specifically in the Northern Cape region of South Africa, and parts of Southern Namibia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Namibia","South Africa"],"other_name":["Quiver Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Aloidendron dichotomum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and less vigorous. Ensure it is planted where it can receive some direct sunlight, particularly in the mornings, to maintain its robust growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Reynoutria sachalinensis is essential to control its vigorous growth and prevent it from becoming invasive. It's best to prune the plant in late autumn or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the stems to ground level to encourage fresh growth and manage size. Regularly remove any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth. Additionally, remove any unwanted shoots throughout the growing season to control spread. Proper disposal of pruned material is important as cuttings can root and propagate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Giant Knotweed","description":"Reynoutria sachalinensis (giant knotweed or Sakhalin knotweed Japanese オオイタドリ ooitadori, Russian Горец сахалинский, Гречиха сахалинская; syns. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19689,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronica salicifolia, commonly known as koromiko, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It's essential not to let the plant dry out completely between waterings. In hotter months, water regularly to ensure the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged, which can lead to root rot. In cooler months, reduce watering and allow the top layer of soil to dry slightly before re-watering. Mulching can help maintain soil moisture levels. Always consider the local climate and soil conditions to adjust the watering schedule appropriately."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronica salicifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure optimal growth and blooming. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent overheating and dehydration. In cooler climates, placing it in a location with maximum sunlight exposure is recommended. Too much shade can result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. Ensure the plant is protected from harsh afternoon sun, especially in peak summer, to avoid leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Veronica salicifolia is beneficial to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune after flowering, usually in late spring or early summer, to remove spent flower spikes and any dead or diseased wood. Trim back overgrown stems to encourage bushier growth and enhance air circulation. A general rule is not to remove more than one-third of the plant's total growth at one time. Avoid pruning too late in the season, as new growth might not harden off before winter. Always use sharp and sterilized tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"koromiko","description":"Hebe salicifolia, the koromiko, or willow-leaf hebe, is a plant of the family Plantaginaceae, which is found throughout the South Island of New Zealand and in Chile. It is large, evergreen shrub, reaching 2 m in height, with light green, spear-shaped leaves that are up to 12 cm long. Flowers are white or pale lilac.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["koromiko"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Veronica salicifolia"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Use clean and sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts, thereby reducing the risk of diseases. It primarily absorbs moisture and nutrients from its host tree. In cultivation, it's essential to maintain the health of the host plant and ensure it has adequate water supply. If grown independently for study purposes, ensure the medium is consistently moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to rot. Monitoring the host plant’s needs will indirectly guide the watering approach for the mistletoe."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phoradendron villosum generally thrives in filtered sunlight, matching the light conditions of its typical host environment in woodlands. Since it usually grows attached to tree branches, it is accustomed to dappled sunlight that filters through the canopy. In cultivation, mimic these conditions by providing bright, indirect light. Direct exposure to harsh sunlight can dry out the plant, whereas too little light might inhibit growth. Observing its natural habitat gives clues to optimizing light conditions for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Phoradendron villosum should be minimal and mainly for control or health purposes. Since it's a parasitic plant, significant pruning might harm its delicate attachment to the host. Carefully remove only overly dense or dead sections to encourage better air circulation and reduce disease risk. Conduct any pruning during the dormant season of the host plant to minimize stress. Ensure cuts are clean to prevent infection, and observe the host plant’s response to ensure overall health is maintained."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"oak mistletoe","description":"Phoradendron villosum is a species of flowering plant in the sandalwood family known by the common names Pacific mistletoe and oak mistletoe. This species is native to South Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18588,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Osmanthus fragrans, also known as fragrant tea olive, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It's important to water the plant deeply and then allow the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. During the growing season, spring through summer, it may require more frequent watering, approximately once a week. In the dormant winter period, reduce watering as the plant needs less moisture but do not let the soil completely dry out. Always consider humidity levels and rainfall in your area to adjust the frequency of watering accordingly to avoid overwatering and root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Osmanthus fragrans thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight for optimal blooming. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching and reduce stress on the plant. If grown indoors, place the plant in a bright, south-facing window. It's adaptable to various light conditions but may produce fewer flowers if kept in too much shade. Watch for signs such as leggy growth or reduced flowering, which indicate the plant needs more light. Adjust the location gradually to acclimate the plant to its new light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Osmanthus fragrans to maintain shape and encourage new growth. Best done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any dead, damaged, or crossed branches. You can also trim back the tips of branches to control size and shape or to stimulate denser foliage. If you are shaping a hedge, regular light pruning throughout the growing season is acceptable. Be cautious not to over-prune as this may reduce blooming, since flowers form on the previous year's growth. Lightly thinning the plant helps improve air circulation and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sweet olive","description":"Osmanthus fragrans (lit. \"fragrant osmanthus\"; Chinese: 桂花, guìhuā, and 木樨, mùxī; Cantonese Yale: gwai fā; Japanese: 木犀, mokusei; Hindi: सिलंग, silang), variously known as sweet osmanthus, sweet olive, tea olive, and fragrant olive, is a species native to Asia from the Himalayas through southern China (Guizhou, Sichuan, Yunnan) to Taiwan and southern Japan and southeast Asia as far south as Cambodia and Thailand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan"],"other_name":["Sweet olive"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Osmanthus fragrans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18795,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thelymitra pulchella, commonly known as the sun orchid, requires careful watering to mimic its natural environment. It prefers a dry period in the dormant stage (summer) and adequate moisture during the growing season (autumn and winter). Water the plant regularly during its growth period, but avoid waterlogging which can cause root rot. Ensure the soil is well-drained, and it is best to allow the top layer of the soil to slightly dry out between waterings. Use rainwater or distilled water if possible, as they replicate the plant's natural habitat conditions better than tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thelymitra pulchella thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, similar to its natural habitat. It prefers morning sun or dappled shade if grown outdoors, which helps to mimic its native environment conditions. When grown indoors or in a greenhouse, place the plant near a south-facing window with filtered light. Avoid direct harsh afternoon sun, as it can scorch the leaves. If the light level is too low, it might not bloom. Therefore, ensuring it receives the right amount of sunlight is crucial for its growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thelymitra pulchella is generally minimal. After flowering and during its dormant period, remove any dead or dying flowers and leaves to direct the plant’s energy into new growth when it begins its active phase again. Be cautious not to cut the healthy parts of the plant as orchids are sensitive and any damage could affect future growth. Clean scissors or pruning shears should be used to avoid spreading diseases, and cuts should be made at the base to prevent any potential for rot or disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"striped sun orchid","description":"Thelymitra pulchella, commonly called the striped sun orchid, is a species of orchid in the family Orchidaceae that is endemic to New Zealand. Therefore, if cultivating it in a lab or controlled environment, maintaining high humidity levels and ensuring the growth substrate (decaying wood) retains some natural moisture is crucial. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it may dry out the substrate or increase temperature levels beyond the comfort range for fungal development. Humidity levels are more crucial than light for its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for fungi like Spongipellis pachyodon as it is for plants. However, maintaining a healthy growth environment involves removing any damaged or decaying parts of the wood the fungus is growing on to prevent contamination or disease spread. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18589,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Terminalia mantaly, commonly known as the Madagascar almond, is a drought-tolerant plant that does not require frequent watering once established. During the initial growth phase, regular watering is necessary to help the plant establish a strong root system. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. Once mature, it generally requires watering only during extended dry periods. Too much water can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil drains well and allow the top few centimeters to dry out between watering. Reduce watering significantly during the winter months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Terminalia mantaly prefers full sun to partial shade but thrives best with at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. In tropical and subtropical regions, it can tolerate more intense sunlight, while in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade might prevent leaf scorching. Planted in an open area without obstruction, it will achieve its best growth and strongest shape. When planting indoors, choose a spot near a bright window if outside sun isn’t available. Adequate sunlight exposure is crucial for healthy leaves and the plant's overall symmetrical growth form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Terminalia mantaly is essential to maintain its characteristic layered, pagoda-like shape. Prune in late winter or early spring while the plant is dormant. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches first. Thin out any crowded areas to allow light and air to penetrate the inner branches, promoting healthy growth. Trim back any branches that disrupt the layered appearance to maintain the plant’s aesthetic appeal. Light pruning throughout the growing season can help to shape and control its size. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Madagascar almond","description":"Terminalia neotaliala, the Madagascar almond tree, is a mid-sized tree in the leadwood tree family, Combretaceae. Endemic to Madagascar, at maturity, the tree grows from 10 to 20 m (33 to 66 ft) tall. It is an invasive species on the continent of Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Madagascar"],"other_name":["Madagascar almond"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Terminalia mantaly"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19484,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stilbe vestita prefers well-drained soil and requires moderate watering. The watering schedule should be adapted to the climate and conditions in which the plant is grown. In general, allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, especially in compact soil with poor drainage. During the active growing season in spring and summer, the plant may require more frequent watering, but in the cooler months, reduce watering to prevent moisture retention in the soil. Always check the soil moisture before watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stilbe vestita thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. When planted in full sun, ensure the plant receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from intense heat, which may scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, place the plant near a sunny window where it can receive bright, indirect sunlight. Adequate sunlight helps maintain its vibrant foliage and encourages blooming. Adjust exposure according to specific conditions to avoid stressing the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stilbe vestita should be done sparingly and with care, primarily to remove dead or damaged stems. Pruning should ideally be conducted in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges. This practice helps promote a neat appearance and encourages healthy growth. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the plant and affect its natural growth habit. Simply trimming back any overgrown or unruly stems can help maintain the desired shape. Utilize clean and sharp pruning tools to ensure a smooth cut and to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Robust Candlestick","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["Robust Candlestick"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Stilbe vestita"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18693,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia mauritanica, a drought-tolerant succulent, requires minimal watering. Water sparingly, allowing the soil to completely dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure proper drainage. Generally, during the growing season, water every two weeks; in the dormant winter months, reduce watering to once a month or even less, depending on humidity levels. Always water deeply, letting excess water drain away completely, but avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia mauritanica thrives in bright sunlight and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to remain healthy and vibrant. However, in extremely hot climates or during intense midday sun, some protection might be necessary to prevent sunburn. Ideally, place the plant in a south-facing window or outdoors where it can receive ample sunlight. When growing the plant indoors, supplement with artificial lighting if natural light is insufficient to mimic its natural environment and ensure robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia mauritanica is minimal and typically involves removing any damaged or dead stems to promote health and aesthetics. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts. Be cautious of the plant's milky sap, which can be irritating to skin and eyes. Wear gloves and goggles for protection, and consider doing this task during the plant's dormant period in late winter to early spring. Pruning also helps control size and shape, especially if the plant is being kept in a container."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Milkbush","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa"],"other_name":["Yellow Milkbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia mauritanica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18194,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Campanula cochleariifolia, also known as the fairies' thimble, prefers consistent moisture but does not like to sit in waterlogged soil. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil remains slightly moist, especially during its growing season in the spring and summer. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant. It's important to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot, but never let it dry completely. Mulching can help retain moisture and maintain even soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Campanula cochleariifolia thrives in full to partial sunlight. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing afternoon shade can help prevent scorched leaves and stressed roots. When planted in a garden, choose a spot that gets morning sun and afternoon shade. For indoor growth, place the plant near a bright window, but it's crucial to avoid too much harsh, direct sunlight, which can damage the leaves. Ensure the plant has good air circulation to mimic its preferred natural alpine habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Campanula cochleariifolia involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming throughout the growing season. This not only tidies the plant but also directs energy towards producing more flowers. After the flowering season, cut back the flowering stems to maintain a neat appearance and promote healthy growth next year. Remove any dead or diseased foliage promptly. In late fall, trim back the plants for overwintering, but leave some stems to protect the crown from winter cold. Regularly remove any yellow or damaged leaves to keep the plant healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fairy's-thimble","description":"Campanula cochleariifolia (also Campanula cochlearifolia), common name earleaf bellflower or fairy's-thimble, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Campanula of the family Campanulaceae, native to the Pyrenees, Alps, and Carpathian Mountains of Central Europe. It is a rhizomatous herbaceous perennial growing to 10 cm (4 in). Clumps of bright green leaves produce nodding pale blue bell flowers on wiry stalks.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Fairy's-thimble"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Campanula cochleariifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to mimic its natural habitat by allowing the soil to almost dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so during its active growing period in the spring, watering should be moderate. In its dormant season, when the plant is less active, water sparingly or not at all, depending on humidity levels and local climate conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Caladenia tentaculata requires filtered sunlight to thrive, emulating its native woodland and heathland environments. It does best in dappled light or partial shade, as direct sunlight can scorch its delicate leaves and flowers. If grown inside, placing the plant near a window with sheer curtains can provide appropriate light conditions. Ensuring it receives morning sun and afternoon shade can mimic the outdoor conditions, helping to maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Caladenia tentaculata is minimal, primarily focusing on the removal of dead or yellowing leaves and spent flower stems to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. This should be done gently to avoid damaging the plant. After flowering has ended, cutting back the flower stem can help direct the plant's energy back into the bulb. Always use sterile pruning tools to prevent the spread of pathogens and ensure cuts are clean to promote fast healing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern mantis orchid","description":"Caladenia tentaculata, commonly known as the eastern mantis orchid, large green-comb, green comb or fringed spider orchid is a plant in the orchid family Orchidaceae and is endemic to south-eastern Australia. It is a ground orchid with a single, hairy leaf and up to three green flowers with red stripes on the sepals and petals.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["eastern mantis orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Caladenia tentaculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18292,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agrocybe putaminum, being a type of mushroom, doesn't require traditional watering like most plants. Instead, maintaining a high humidity environment is essential for its growth. Spraying the growing medium lightly with water daily or keeping a humidity dome or tent over the growing area can help maintain an adequate moisture level. It is important to keep the environment damp but not overly wet to prevent mold and bacterial growth. Always ensure there is good air circulation to avoid stagnation, which can be harmful to mushroom growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agrocybe putaminum, like many mushrooms, does not need direct sunlight. Mushrooms generally require indirect light or low light conditions to thrive. A dimly lit area or a location with filtered light, like under a shade cloth, is often ideal. This type of environment mimics their natural habitat on the forest floor. To provide appropriate lighting, consider using fluorescent or LED grow lights set on a timer to simulate a day/night cycle, replicating natural conditions without exposing them to too much direct light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning does not apply to Agrocybe putaminum in the traditional sense, as it is a mushroom and not a plant with leaves or branches. Instead, focus on harvesting the mushrooms correctly. When the caps of the mushrooms fully open, cut them at the base with a clean knife or scissors to prevent damage to the mycelium, allowing for continued and healthy fruiting. Regularly remove any decayed or malformed mushrooms to encourage better air circulation and prevent contamination."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mulch Fieldcap","description":"Agrocybe putaminum, commonly known as the mulch fieldcap, is a species of agaric fungus in the family Strophariaceae in the Agrocybe sororia complex. Described as new to science in 1913, it is found in Asia, Australia, Europe, and western North America, where it grows in parks, gardens, and roadsides in woodchip mulch. Fruitbodies of the fungus have a dull brownish-orange cap with a matte texture, a grooved stipe, and a bitter, mealy taste.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Mulch Fieldcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agrocybe putaminum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18993,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Ulmus laevis, also known as the European white elm, prefers moist but well-drained soil conditions. When establishing the tree, regular watering is essential to help develop a robust root system. Once the tree is mature, it generally requires less frequent watering. During dry spells or hot weather, ensure the soil remains moist by watering the tree every 7-10 days, especially if it hasn’t rained. It’s important to avoid waterlogging as the tree does not tolerate standing water well. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil and regulate temperature, reducing the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ulmus laevis thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which will support optimal growth and a healthy canopy. However, the tree is tolerant of some shade, especially considering its adaptive nature in various environmental conditions. While the tree can survive in shaded areas, its growth may not be as robust or symmetrical compared to when it's planted in a sunnier location. Ensure that surrounding vegetation or structures do not excessively block sunlight from reaching the tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ulmus laevis is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This timing helps minimize stress and the risk of disease. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain a healthy structure. Additionally, thinning the canopy slightly can improve air circulation, which is vital for preventing fungal diseases. Avoid excess pruning, which can stress the tree. Young trees may need more structural pruning to establish a strong framework compared to mature trees that only require maintenance pruning to remove problematic branches."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fluttering Elm","description":"Ulmus laevis Pall., variously known as the European white elm, fluttering elm, spreading elm, stately elm and, in the USA, the Russian elm, is a large deciduous tree native to Europe, from France northeast to southern Finland, east as far as the Urals, and southeast to Bulgaria and the Crimea; there are also disjunct populations in the Caucasus and Spain, the latter now considered a relict population rather than an introduction by man, and possibly the...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Fluttering Elm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Dutch elm disease","Elm beetle","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ulmus laevis"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19089,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acer pseudosieboldianum, commonly known as the Korean maple, requires moderate watering. It's crucial to check the top inch of soil; water the plant when this layer begins to feel dry. In dry spells and during hot summer months, increase the frequency of watering to ensure the tree receives adequate moisture. Mulching around the base helps retain soil moisture and keeps the roots cool. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely during the growing season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer pseudosieboldianum thrives in partial to full sun exposure. Ideally, the plant should receive morning sunlight and be protected from harsh afternoon sun, especially in hotter climates where intense light can lead to leaf scorch. Ensure the tree is in a location where it gets at least a few hours of direct sunlight each day to support healthy growth and vibrant autumn foliage. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and the fall coloration could be less intense. Adjust the plant's sunlight exposure gradually to prevent stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer pseudosieboldianum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. The aim is to maintain the tree’s natural shape and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood. Prune away crossing branches to improve air circulation and allow light to penetrate the canopy, which can help prevent disease. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the tree and affect its overall health. For mature trees, light thinning can help maintain a more open structure. Regularly removing weak or congested branches will promote healthy growth and a more aesthetically pleasing form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Korean maple","description":"Acer pseudosieboldianum, the Korean maple or purplebloom maple, is a species of maple. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18195,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Utricularia australis, commonly known as the Southern Bladderwort, is an aquatic carnivorous plant. It prefers soft, slightly acidic to neutral water, often found in nutrient-poor conditions. Ensure the plants are submerged or floating on water sources that are free of pollutants and excessive algae, as too much organic matter might negatively impact its growth. Maintaining clear, clean water is crucial to mimic its natural habitat and ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia australis prefers bright, indirect sunlight and typically thrives in full sun to partial shade. In its natural habitat, it can be found in sunny, open spaces or slightly shaded conditions under dappled light from surrounding vegetation. When cultivating this plant, aim to provide at least 6 hours of bright light per day, ideally simulating natural outdoor conditions. If growing indoors or in an aquarium, using artificial grow lights can supplement light requirements. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light supports photosynthesis which is vital for its growth and the health of its traps for capturing prey."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Utricularia australis, as it naturally regulates its growth. However, regular maintenance can involve removing dead or decaying plant material to prevent decomposition that could alter water quality. If the plant becomes overly dense, you can thin it out to encourage better water flow and light penetration, simply by cutting back excess growth. Ensure that you are not pruning too aggressively, as this plant relies on its foliage for capturing sunlight and nutrients. Routine checks can help in maintaining its aesthetic appeal and optimal health in controlled environments."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Yellow bladderwort","description":"Utricularia australis is a medium-sized, perennial species of aquatic bladderwort. This species has a vast geographic range, being found throughout Europe, in tropical and temperate Asia including China and Japan in the east, Central and Southern Africa, Australia and the North Island of New Zealand. The specific epithet \"australis\" is Latin for \"southern\" and reflects the fact that the discovery of this species was made in Australia in 1810.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["Yellow bladderwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Utricularia australis"],"soil":["Aquatic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18491,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio angulatus, also known as climbing groundsel, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered moderately. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the active growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently to keep the soil slightly moist, but be cautious not to soak it. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly as the plant's growth slows down. Always consider environmental factors like humidity and temperature when determining your watering schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio angulatus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates. Ideally, place the plant in a location where it can receive at least four to six hours of bright light, which promotes healthy growth and flowering. If you're growing it indoors, place it near a south-facing window with filtered sunlight. Avoid placing it in deep shade as it may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. For outdoor plants, a spot with morning sun and afternoon shade is optimal to prevent leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio angulatus is essential to maintain its shape and manage its growth as it can be quite vigorous. Prune the plant in the spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and to control its size. You can also remove up to a third of the plant's growth to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts above leaf nodes to encourage new growth. Regular pruning also helps prevent the plant from becoming too leggy and keeps it healthy and attractive during the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping groundsel","description":"Senecio angulatus also known as Creeping groundsel and sometimes as Cape ivy is a climbing succulent perennial from the family Asteraceae of the genus Senecio; a native of South Africa an alien in Australia, a problem weed in New Zealand, naturalized in North Africa, and cultivated elsewhere.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["creeping groundsel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Senecio angulatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18590,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyanus montanus, commonly known as perennial cornflower or mountain bluet, requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. However, ensure not to overwater as it can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. In winter, reduce watering frequency but do not let the plant dry out completely. Well-drained soil will prevent waterlogging and encourage healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyanus montanus thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce abundant blooms. If placed in a spot with partial shade, ensure it receives adequate morning sunlight as it helps in strong growth and reduces susceptibilities to common diseases. Too much shade can result in spindly growth and fewer flowers. When planting, choose a location with full sun, especially in cooler climates, while providing afternoon shade in hotter zones to protect the plant from excessive heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cyanus montanus should be done to encourage healthy growth and maintain its shape. After the flowering period, usually in midsummer, deadhead the spent flowers to encourage a second bloom. Cut back the entire plant by about one-third to help rejuvenate it. In late autumn, prune back to ground level to prepare for winter. This not only keeps the plant tidy but also helps reduce the risk of pests and diseases overwintering in the old foliage. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Perennial Cornflower","description":"Centaurea montana (perennial cornflower, mountain cornflower, bachelor's button, montane knapweed or mountain bluet) is a species of Centaurea endemic to Europe. It is widespread and common in the more southerly mountain ranges of Europe, but is rarer in the north. It escapes from gardens readily, and has thereby become established in the British Isles, Scandinavia and North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Perennial Cornflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cyanus montanus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19287,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Muraltia spinosa is a hardy, drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During its growing season, water it moderately to keep the soil slightly moist but not water-logged. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant goes dormant and excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Ideally, allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering. It's important to adjust the frequency based on the local climate conditions, especially in areas with high rainfall. Always ensure good drainage to prevent water accumulation around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Muraltia spinosa thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure healthy growth and abundant flowering. It's well-suited to bright, sunny conditions and should be placed in a location that receives full exposure throughout the day. While it can tolerate light shade, too much shading may result in reduced flowering and a leggier growth habit. Ensure the plant is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures. In extremely hot climates, partial afternoon shade can protect it from excessive heat, but generally, more sunlight promotes optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Muraltia spinosa is essential to maintain its shape and encourage bushy, healthy growth. It's best to prune it in early spring before the growing season begins, cutting back any dead or damaged branches to stimulate new growth. Additionally, light pruning throughout the growing season can help control its size and remove any unwanted growth. Practice caution not to over-prune, as Muraltia spinosa blooms on old wood, and cutting too much can reduce the flowering potential. Make sure to use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tortoise berry","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["tortoise berry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Muraltia spinosa"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18196,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypochaeris maculata, commonly known as Spotted Cat's Ear or Spotted Hypochaeris, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. Allow the soil to almost dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During hot, dry periods, you may need to water more frequently, ensuring not to overwater. The key is to maintain consistent moisture during the growing season without the soil becoming waterlogged. Reduce watering during winter months as the plant’s growth slows down. Always check the top inch of soil for dryness before watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypochaeris maculata thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure robust growth and abundant flowering. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf burn and dehydration. If grown in shady areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ensure it is planted in a position where it receives ample sunlight, especially during the peak growing seasons of spring and summer, for optimal health and aesthetics."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypochaeris maculata is relatively straightforward. Remove spent blooms regularly to encourage further flowering and maintain a tidy appearance. This deadheading process helps direct the plant's energy towards new growth and flowering. As the plant can become somewhat sprawling, you can trim back any excessive or unwanted growth to keep it compact. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged leaves and stems throughout the growing season to promote healthy growth and prevent any potential pest or disease problems. Pruning is best done in early spring or after flowering to shape the plant as desired."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spotted Cat's-ear","description":"Hypochaeris maculata is a species of flowering plant belonging to the family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Spotted Cat's-ear"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Hypochaeris maculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
