{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18492,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio tamoides require moderate watering. It prefers soil that's allowed to dry out slightly between waterings, as it is somewhat drought-tolerant. You should water it when the first couple of inches of soil feel dry to the touch. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure proper drainage in the pot to avoid water logging. During active growing seasons, like spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, but in the cooler months, reduce watering to prevent damp conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio tamoides thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It benefits most from around 6 to 8 hours of sunlight daily. However, in very hot climates or intense afternoon sun, it might appreciate some afternoon shade to prevent leaf burn. Adequate sunlight promotes healthy growth and vibrant blooms, but too much direct, harsh sun can be detrimental."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio tamoides can help manage its vine-like growth and encourage a bushier appearance. It’s best to prune in spring after the risk of frost has passed and before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain plant health. You can also pinch back the tips of the plant to encourage branching. Be careful not to over-prune since it could stress the plant; instead, focus on maintaining a balanced shape and removing any unwanted overgrowth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Canary creeper","description":"Senecio tamoides or also known as Canary creeper (a name it shares with Senecio deltoideus Less.) is a climbing member of the genus Senecio of the family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Canary creeper"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Senecio tamoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18294,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agaricus bernardii, also known as the \"salt-loving mushroom,\" does not require traditional plant care instructions like watering as it is a fungus that typically grows in saline environments like coastal areas. However, if cultivated, ensure the growing medium is kept consistently moist but not overly saturated, mimicking its natural habitat conditions. Allow the substrate to dry slightly between watering to avoid fungal diseases and ensure aeration. Moisture management is key as mushrooms absorb water from the substrate rather than being watered directly like traditional plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mushrooms like Agaricus bernardii do not require direct sunlight, as they thrive in dim light conditions typically found in their natural habitat under substrates. Direct sunlight can dry out the growing media, so it's best to grow them in shaded or indirectly lit areas. If cultivated indoors, a low-light environment away from direct sun is ideal. Providing consistent humidity and temperature is more crucial than sunlight exposure for optimal growth. Aim for an environment that maintains a stable temperature with indirect lighting conditions to replicate its natural habitat for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike traditional plants, Agaricus bernardii and other mushrooms do not require pruning. However, proper management involves careful harvesting by gently twisting or cutting the mushroom at the base when the cap is fully developed but before it begins to flatten or upturn. This encourages further flushes and prevents decay on residual stubs. Handling the mushroom gently prevents damage to the mycelium network, allowing continued growth and production. Keeping the growing area clean and removing any spent or rotting mushrooms can help prevent contamination and promote healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Salt-loving Agaricus","description":"Agaricus bernardii, commonly called the salt-loving mushroom, is an agaric fungus in the family Agaricaceae. A short, squat mushroom, the thick stem is usually less than the diameter of the cap, which ranges from 5–15 cm (2.0–5.9 in). Found in Asia, Europe, North America, and New Zealand, it is a salt-tolerant species that grows in salt marshes, dunes, and coastal grassland. The fungus produces fruit bodies (mushrooms) with convex to flattened caps up to 15 cm (5.9 in) in diameter,...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Salt-loving Agaricus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Agaricus bernardii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Monitor the leaves for signs of sunburn (browning or yellowing) which indicate excessive sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anticlea occidentalis should be minimal, focusing primarily on maintaining the plant's health and encouraging vigorous growth. Generally, remove any dead or damaged leaves and old flower stems after they have bloomed to keep the plant tidy and prevent disease. Be cautious not to cut back healthy foliage as the plant uses these to store energy for its next flowering cycle. To cultivate similar mushrooms, maintain a consistently moist environment by ensuring the growing medium (such as a substrate) remains damp. This can be achieved by regular misting or using a humidity tent to trap moisture, mimicking the mushroom's native habitat with high humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tylopilus rubrobrunneus grows naturally in shaded forested areas, so it does not require direct sunlight. Consistent, moderate light levels help ensure optimal growth and development without drying out the substrate or growing medium."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mushrooms, including Tylopilus rubrobrunneus, do not require pruning like typical garden plants. Instead, when cultivating these fungi, focus on harvesting. Harvest mushrooms by gently twisting and pulling them from the substrate when they reach maturity and before they begin to decompose. Removing mature or nearly mature mushrooms can encourage the growth of new mushrooms. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19487,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heeria argentea, like many succulents, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered sparingly. Allow the soil to completely dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Typically during the growing season (spring and summer), you may need to water every 2-3 weeks, whereas in the dormant season (fall and winter), watering can be reduced to once a month or even less. It is essential to adjust the frequency depending on the humidity and temperature of your environment, ensuring that the plant is not left in soggy conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heeria argentea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can be too intense and may cause scorching, while too little light can lead to leggy growth. The ideal location is by a window that receives filtered light or several hours of gentle morning sun. If indoors, placing the plant near an east or west-facing window is often suitable. Monitoring the plant's reaction to its placement is crucial, as signs of sunburn or etiolation (stretching) will indicate the need for adjustments in lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heeria argentea is generally minimal, focusing mainly on maintaining shape and removing any dead or unhealthy growth. Occasionally, trim off any wilted or dried leaves to keep the plant looking tidy and to prevent any potential pest issues. If the plant becomes leggy, which can occur if it's not receiving enough light, prune it back to encourage more compact growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and the risk of infection. Pruning is best done during the growing season as the plant will heal faster."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rockwood","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silver"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Rockwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Heeria argentea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19693,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronica speciosa, commonly known as Hebe, thrives in well-drained soil and requires regular watering, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Ensure the soil is consistently moist, but not waterlogged, as soggy roots can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply, allowing excess water to drain completely. In the cooler months, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows. Always check the soil moisture before watering by inserting your finger about an inch deep; if it feels dry, it’s time to water. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases on foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronica speciosa flourishes with ample sunlight and should be placed in a location where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. Ideally, position it in a spot that benefits from full morning sun with some protection from the harsh afternoon rays, especially in hot climates. In hotter regions, a site with dappled afternoon shade helps prevent foliage scorch, whereas in cooler areas, full sun is generally beneficial. Good light exposure ensures robust blooms and maintains the vibrancy of the foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To keep Veronica speciosa looking its best, prune lightly after it finishes flowering to remove spent blooms and encourage bushier growth. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to cut back any dead or diseased stems, and shape the plant by trimming long, leggy branches. Lightly thin the shrub to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Older plants can benefit from rejuvenation pruning by cutting back some of the older branches to a lower node, encouraging new growth. Additionally, adequate sunlight reduces the moisture level on leaves due to rapid drying, thus reducing the chances of rust development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not directly applicable to Puccinia malvacearum, as it is a fungus affecting plants. However, pruning the host plant to remove affected leaves and promote better air circulation can help mitigate the spread of rust. Regularly inspect plants and prune diseased foliage as soon as it appears, which can help control and limit the development and outbreak of rust fungi in your garden."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Hollyhock Rust","description":"Puccinia malvacearum, also known as hollyhock or mallow rust, is a species within the Puccinia genus known for attacking members of the Malvaceae family. Ensuring ample sunlight encourages strong, healthy growth and vibrant flowering. If grown in hotter climates, it can also tolerate partial shade, especially in the afternoons, to prevent excessive drying and sun scorch. Choose a site with good sunlight exposure to ensure the best performance of this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jacobaea erucifolia involves removing spent flower heads to encourage a tidier appearance and potentially prolong blooming. Deadhead the flowers as they fade, which can prevent self-seeding if that is undesired. In early spring, cut back old and dead stems to make way for new growth, which helps maintain vigor. In cases where the plant has spread too much or is getting sparse, you can perform more extensive pruning to shape or reduce its overall size. Prune with clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hoary Ragwort","description":"Jacobaea erucifolia or hoary ragwort (synonym Senecio erucifolius) is a species of the genus Jacobaea and the family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Hoary Ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Jacobaea erucifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When cultivating, place it in a dimly lit area that simulates these natural environments, ensuring that it does not receive direct sunlight, which can dry out the substrate and harm the mushrooms. Indirect light, such as that from a shaded window or fluorescent lighting, is typically sufficient to support its growth. Proper light management will help promote healthy and optimal fruiting of the mushrooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to mushrooms like Lactarius argillaceifolius in the same way it is to plants. Mushrooms do not have structures like leaves, branches, or stems that require pruning. However, during the fruiting period, removing mature or over-mature mushrooms by cutting or gently twisting helps to prevent rot and makes space for new fruiting bodies. This also maintains cleanliness in the growing area, reducing the risk of pests and diseases. Always handle the mushrooms gently to avoid disturbing the mycelium or other mushrooms growing nearby."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Clay-gilled Milkcap","description":"Lactarius argillaceifolius is a species of fungus in the Russulaceae family. Ensure that the host plant receives its required sunlight conditions to maintain overall plant health and the parasitic relationship, observing the host's leaf color and growth for signs of stress due to excessive or insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aphyllon purpureum is not typically required, as it is a small, parasitic plant that often relies on its host for structure and support. However, if the broomrape becomes too dense or starts to negatively impact the host plant's growth by over-parasitizing, you may carefully trim some of the stems. Always use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to prevent any potential disease transmission and ensure that trimming does not damage the host plant's structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"oneflower broomrape","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["oneflower broomrape"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aphyllon purpureum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In controlled environments, maintaining high humidity may facilitate its growth on host fungi but direct watering is unnecessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spinellus fusiger thrives in conditions that favor its mushroom hosts, which are typically found in damp, shaded, or semi-shaded areas such as forest floors. Direct sunlight is not beneficial and may even inhibit its growth. Instead, this fungus prefers low light conditions; replicating these can help sustain its lifecycle. In artificial settings, indirect light or low-intensity artificial light sources can mimic the dappled sunlight of its natural habitat, supporting the fungal hosts and consequently the growth of Spinellus fusiger."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a parasitic fungus rather than a plant, Spinellus fusiger does not require pruning in the conventional sense. Ensuring suitable environmental conditions and removing unwanted fungal hosts can help manage their prevalence. In research or natural study settings, controlling the host population will assist in managing Spinellus fusiger populations effectively."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bonnet mold","description":"Spinellus fusiger, commonly known as the bonnet mold, is a species of fungus in the Zygomycota phylum. It is a pin mold that is characterized by erect sporangiophores (specialized hyphae that bear a sporangium) that are simple in structure, brown or yellowish-brown in color, and with branched aerial filaments that bear the zygospores. It grows as a parasitic mold on mushrooms, including several species from the genera Mycena, including M. haematopus, M. pura, M. epipterygia, M. leptocephala, and various Collybia...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["bonnet mold"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Spinellus fusiger"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Use a gentle touch to avoid damaging the mycelium network."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scarletina Bolete","description":"Neoboletus luridiformis, known until 2014 as Boletus luridiformis, is a fungus of the bolete family, all of which produce mushrooms with tubes and pores beneath their caps. If attempting to cultivate or study it, ensure that it mimics its native conditions by avoiding overly sunny and dry areas, and emulate the filtered light typical under forest canopies."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Amanita xanthocephala, as it is a type of mushroom and not a plant with stems or leaves that require trimming. Mushrooms generally do not require nor benefit from pruning. Instead, focus should be placed on providing it with suitable growing conditions and avoiding disruption of its natural environment. Care should be taken when harvesting to ensure that the base and surrounding mycelium are left intact to promote further growth."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Vermilion Amanita","description":"The vermilion grisette, also known as pretty grisette or vermilion Amanita (Amanita xanthocephala) is a colourful mushroom of the genus Amanita. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19202,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aquilegia coerulea, commonly known as the Colorado blue columbine, prefers moist but well-drained soil. Providing some shade will also help maintain soil moisture and protect foliage from sun scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aquilegia coerulea is primarily aimed at promoting better blooming and maintaining plant health. After the plant flowers, deadhead the spent blooms to encourage more flowering and to prevent seed formation if self-sowing is not desired. Once flowering is complete, cut back the flower stalks to the base. In late fall, you can prune the foliage down to the ground to tidy up the plant and prepare it for winter. Removing old, dead leaves also helps prevent disease and adds to the overall appearance of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blue columbine","description":"Aquilegia coerulea is a species of Aquilegia flower native to the Rocky Mountains from Montana south to New Mexico and west to Idaho and Arizona. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19292,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kalanchoe rotundifolia, like most succulents, prefers minimal watering. Allow the topsoil to dry out completely before watering again to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, watering once every 1-2 weeks is usually sufficient. In the dormant season, fall and winter, reduce watering to once a month, depending on the humidity and light conditions. Always ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogged soil, and consider using a well-draining cactus potting mix to optimize plant health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalanchoe rotundifolia thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can be kept indoors near a window that receives a good amount of light, but it’s essential to avoid direct, harsh sunlight especially during the midday hours, as this can scorch the leaves. If grown outdoors, position it in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and diminish flowering. Therefore, ensure it receives at least four to six hours of bright, indirect light daily for optimal health and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalanchoe rotundifolia is beneficial to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. It is best to prune in the spring after the plant has finished flowering. Remove any dead or wilted flowers by pinching them off at the base. Trim away any leggy or unhealthy stems to promote a fuller growth habit. Always use a pair of sharp, sterilized scissors to prevent disease from affecting the plant. Pruned healthy clippings can often be propagated to create new plants, adding to your succulent collection."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Nentakalanchoe","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Nentakalanchoe"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Kalanchoe rotundifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19491,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Begonia formosana prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Ensure the pot has drainage holes to prevent waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, maintain a regular watering schedule, but reduce the frequency in fall and winter when the plant enters a dormant phase. Using room temperature water will help prevent stress to the plant. Misting the leaves occasionally can also help increase humidity, especially in dry indoor environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Begonia formosana thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it’s best to place the plant near a window with filtered sunlight or sheer curtains. An east or north-facing window provides ideal lighting conditions, but if only south or west exposures are available, keep the plant a few feet away from the window to protect it from intense afternoon sun. If grown outdoors, a shaded area or dappled sunlight setting is ideal. Consistent light levels will support the plant's growth and flowering patterns."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Begonia formosana is essential to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Regularly remove any dead or yellowing leaves, which can accumulate and attract pests or disease. Trim back leggy stems to promote a more compact and aesthetically pleasing form. The best time to prune is during its active growth period in spring and summer. Using clean and sharp pruning tools, make cuts just above leaf nodes to stimulate new growth. Avoid heavy pruning during the plant’s dormant phase in fall and winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Formosana begonia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan"],"other_name":["Formosana begonia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Begonia formosana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19596,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Protea lepidocarpodendron, being a part of the Proteaceae family, prefers moderate watering. It is essential to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions because overwatering can lead to root rot. During the active growing season, which is typically in warmer months, you can water it more regularly, but ensure that the drainage is excellent. In dormant seasons, such as winter, reduce the watering frequency significantly. Always check the top few inches of soil dryness before watering and adjust your watering schedule according to the environmental conditions and plant's response."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Protea lepidocarpodendron thrives best in full sunlight, making it ideal for open, sunny garden spots or positions with six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure ensures robust growth, vibrant flowering, and an overall healthy plant. If you grow it indoors or in less than ideal conditions, ensure plenty of bright, indirect light and rotate the plant periodically to avoid uneven growth. While the plant can tolerate some partial shade, insufficient sunlight might result in leggy growth and reduced flowering, which should be avoided to maintain its aesthetic appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for maintaining the shape and health of Protea lepidocarpodendron. This plant should ideally be pruned after it blooms to promote new growth and to remove dead or unproductive wood. Focus on removing spent flower heads and any branches that appear weak or diseased. Be careful not to prune too aggressively, as Proteas can be sensitive to over-pruning. Ensure your pruning tools are clean and sharp to prevent any disease transmission. Regularly removing old growth will help in opening up the bush for better air circulation and light penetration."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Blackbeard Sugarbush","description":"Protea lepidocarpodendron, the black bearded sugarbush, is a bearded Protea that is placed in the section Speciosae. It grows between one and 2 m tall, with narrowly oblong leaves. Flowerheads are oblong with a purple-black beard and black hairs below the beard. It typically grows in sandstone, fericrete and granite soils in the Western Cape from Cape Town to Kleinmond. It is near-threatened.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Blackbeard Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Protea lepidocarpodendron"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19696,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus virgata prefers to be kept in consistently moist, but not waterlogged, soil. It's important to water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch, ensuring water penetrates to the roots to keep the plant hydrated. Reduce watering slightly in the winter when the plant's growth slows down. Be cautious of overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. Always check the drainage and make sure the plant is not sitting in excess water, as it needs well-drained soil to thrive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus virgata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It should receive several hours of indirect light each day to maintain healthy growth. Avoid direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, as this can scorch the leaves. If the plant is indoors, placing it near a window with filtered light or sheer curtains is ideal. During low-light conditions in winter, consider moving the plant to a brighter location. Ensure a balanced light exposure to prevent uneven growth or leaf drop."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus virgata is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches, and trim back any overgrown areas to maintain a balanced shape. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, and avoid pruning more than a third of the plant at once to reduce stress. Pruning also helps improve air circulation and light penetration, which is beneficial for the plant's overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"figwood","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeast Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["figwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ficus virgata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions. During hotter months or in dry conditions, increase watering slightly, but ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. If grown in regions with intense afternoon heat, providing some shade during those times can help prevent the plant from getting scorched. Ensure the plant is protected from strong, drying winds."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Matthiola sinuata is not extensively required, but occasional trimming can help maintain its shape and promote healthier growth. It's best to prune during the growing season and use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts which help prevent injury to the plant and reduce the risk of infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sea Stock","description":"Matthiola sinuata, commonly known as sea stock, is a coastal plant in the family Brassicaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["Sea Stock"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Matthiola sinuata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19392,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zephyranthes chlorosolen, commonly known as the rain lily, requires moderate watering. It thrives best when allowed to dry out slightly between waterings. During the growing season, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering during their dormant period in winter. Over-watering can lead to bulb rot, so ensure the potting medium has excellent drainage. If planted outdoors, rainfall typically provides sufficient moisture, but ensure to water them during dry spells. Remember, rain lilies prefer to be watered more in the growing season as compared to their dormancy period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zephyranthes chlorosolen flourishes in full to partial sunlight. For optimal growth, provide them with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. They are versatile and can perform well in slightly shaded areas, although flowering might reduce. When grown indoors, place them near a south-facing window where they can receive ample sunlight. In environments with intense sun exposure, it's beneficial to offer some protection during the hottest part of the day. Balancing light exposure ensures robust growth and prolific flowering on these charming plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Zephyranthes chlorosolen is minimal but essential for promoting healthy growth and abundant flowering. Remove spent flowers to prevent the plant from diverting energy into seed production. This also helps in maintaining a tidy appearance. After the flowering period ends, you can trim back any yellow or damaged foliage to encourage new growth. However, avoid cutting too much green foliage since it helps in photosynthesis, vital for bulb storage. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to avoid any damage or infection to the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Brazos rain-lily","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Brazos rain-lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Zephyranthes chlorosolen"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18201,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Artemisia verlotiorum, commonly known as Chinese Mugwort or Verlot's Wormwood, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once established. It is relatively drought-tolerant, so it is important to let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, ensure consistent moisture without waterlogging the soil. In hotter climates or during extremely dry periods, increase watering frequency slightly, but always make sure the top inch of soil is dry before re-watering. Reduce watering significantly during its dormant winter months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Artemisia verlotiorum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure optimal growth and flowering. If placed in an area with too much shade, the plant may become leggy and bloom less profusely. If you live in a region with extremely hot summers, providing the plant with some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Ensuring the right balance of sunlight will keep the plant healthy and support vibrant foliage and flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Artemisia verlotiorum helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Starting in early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to allow new growth to thrive. Throughout the growing season, you can trim the plant to control size and promote bushier growth. After flowering, you might want to cut back the plant to prevent it from becoming too leggy. Be cautious to not over-prune, as this can stress the plant. Always use sharp, clean pruning shears to avoid spreading disease or damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese Mugwort","description":"Artemisia verlotiorum, the Chinese mugwort, is a species of plants in the sunflower family, widespread across much of Eurasia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Asia","Europe"],"other_name":["Chinese Mugwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Artemisia verlotiorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19094,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnopilus thiersii is a mushroom, not a plant, and does not require traditional watering. Instead, it typically grows in humid and moist environments where it can absorb moisture from the air and surrounding substrate. If cultivating this fungus, maintaining a high humidity environment is crucial, usually achieved through misting or using a humidifier in an enclosed space to mimic its natural conditions. Ensure the substrate is damp but not waterlogged, as standing water can lead to rot or other fungal infections."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnopilus thiersii does not require direct sunlight, as it naturally grows on forest decaying wood, primarily relying on ambient light to guide its growth and sporulation. It thrives in shaded, indirect light conditions, ensuring the environment remains humid and moist due to the lack of evaporation caused by direct sunlight. When cultivating, place it in a well-lit but indirect light area to simulate its natural habitats for optimal growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to fungi like Gymnopilus thiersii as it is for plants. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In hotter weather or when the plant is grown in a pot, it may require more frequent watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. As a drought-tolerant plant, it can withstand short periods of dry conditions, but regular watering promotes optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glandora prostrata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal flowering and growth. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. If grown indoors, a south-facing window with plenty of direct sunlight would be ideal. Be mindful of intense midday sun, which can sometimes cause leaf scorching, especially in hotter regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glandora prostrata helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Trim back any dead or damaged branches in early spring before new growth begins. Lightly trimming the plant after its flowering period in late spring or early summer will stimulate further blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. Removing spent flowers can help extend the bloom period and prevent seed formation, which conserves the plant's energy. Regular pruning also prevents the plant from becoming too woody and encourages bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping gromwell","description":"Glandora prostrata, the shrubby gromwell, creeping gromwell or purple gromwell (names it shares with Lithospermum purpurocaeruleum and Glandora diffusa), is a species of Glandora native to Portugal, Spain and France. It thrives in well-drained soil and can tolerate periods of drought once its root system is mature. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings. In its early stages, it may benefit from more frequent watering to help establish the roots, especially in sandy or quick-draining soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senegalia mellifera thrives in full sun environments, requiring a minimum of 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. Placing it in a south-facing position outdoors or near a sunny window indoors will help it maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senegalia mellifera is not strictly necessary but can help maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and prevent pest infestations. Light shaping can control the size and spread of the plant, but avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant. In extreme heat zones, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching, but generally, more sunlight is preferable for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Protea longifolia helps maintain its shape and encourages flowering. Focus on removing dead or damaged stems, crossing branches, and thinning out crowded areas to improve air circulation within the plant. Regular deadheading will also promote longer flowering periods and improve overall plant health. Always sterilize your pruning tools before use to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Long-leaf Sugarbush","description":"Protea longifolia, commonly known as the long-leaf sugarbush, is a shrub of the Proteaceae family that is native to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Long-leaf Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Protea longifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal flowering. While it can tolerate some shade, insufficient light might lead to reduced flowering and leggier growth. In hotter climates, morning sunlight with afternoon shade works well. In Britain it has declined in numbers because of modern farming techniques and draining of wet-lands and is no longer common. Ensure the planting site is open and receives unobstructed sunlight throughout the day for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lagerstroemia subcostata should be done in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. This plant benefits from regular pruning for improved air circulation and to promote vigorous flowering. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. Then, thin out any crossing branches and trim back the previous year's growth by about one-third to encourage a stronger structure. Avoid heavy pruning as this can reduce flowering. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clear cuts, which helps prevent infections. Pruning also helps shape the plant to your desired aesthetic."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Subcostate Crape Myrtle","description":"Lagerstroemia subcostata is a deciduous tree which is native to Japan, Taiwan, China and the Philippines.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Subcostate Crape Myrtle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Lagerstroemia subcostata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18896,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus phaeosticta requires regular watering, especially during its initial growth phase, to establish a robust root system. The soil should remain consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overly saturated conditions can lead to root rot. During the hotter months, increase watering frequency to prevent the soil from drying out completely. In contrast, during the cooler months, reduce watering to avoid excess moisture. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to ensure proper aeration and root health. Mulching can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus phaeosticta thrives best in full sun to partial shade. While it prefers a location that receives plenty of sunlight for at least six hours a day, it can also tolerate light afternoon shade, especially in hotter climates. This adaptability helps prevent leaf scorch during peak summer heat. When planted in less sunny areas, flowering and fruiting may be reduced. Therefore, it is essential to monitor sun exposure during the day and adjust the plant’s placement accordingly to optimize growth and blooming. Avoid deep shade, which can hinder its development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Prunus phaeosticta should typically occur during the dormant period, in late winter or early spring, to encourage healthy growth and flowering. Begin by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain the plant’s vitality and appearance. Thin out dense areas to improve air circulation, which helps prevent fungal diseases. Prune selectively to maintain the desired shape, but avoid cutting back more than one-third of the plant’s overall size in a single session to prevent shock. Regular light pruning encourages bushier growth and a well-balanced structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dark spotted cherry","description":"Prunus phaeosticta, the dark-spotted cherry, is a species of Prunus native to China, including Taiwan, and southeast Asia, including far eastern India, Bangladesh, Burma, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam. It goes by a number of different names in Chinese, including 黑星櫻, black star cherry, 墨點櫻桃 and 墨点樱桃, ink point cherry, and 腺葉桂櫻, gland leaf cherry. It gets its specific epithet and its common names from the small dark spots (glands) on the undersides of its leaves. However, ensure to rotate the plant occasionally to maintain even growth. This should be done regularly throughout the growing season. Use clean, sharp scissors or garden shears for precise cuts. Pinch back the stems to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also help extend the blooming period. It's best to prune in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid stressing the plant during the hottest parts of the day. Allow the top layer to slightly dry between watering schedules, but ensure the underlying substrate remains moist. Rainwater or distilled water is preferable to avoid mineral buildup."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ptychomnion aciculare prefers low to moderate light conditions, mimicking the dappled sunlight of its natural forest floor habitat. It thrives in indirect light, as direct sunlight can cause it to dry out and become stressed. Indoors, place the moss where it receives filtered sunlight or in a shaded area. If outdoors, ensure it is under partial shade, such as a canopy of trees. If artificial lighting is used, ensure the light is not too intense or hot. Maintaining an appropriate light level is crucial for preventing evaporation and ensuring lush growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ptychomnion aciculare is generally minimal, as mosses are slow-growing and do not require frequent trimming. However, to maintain its appearance and promote healthy growth, occasionally remove any dead or discolored parts. This can be done gently by hand or with sterilized scissors to prevent disease spread. Trimming may also help maintain desired shape and density if the moss is part of a decorative feature. Regular grooming helps reduce competition for nutrients and light, enhancing its verdant appearance. Do this sparingly to avoid unnecessary stress on the moss."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pipe-cleaner moss","description":"Ptychomnion aciculare is a species of moss found in Australia, New Zealand, New Caledonia, Samoa, Juan Fernandez Islands and Chile.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["pipe-cleaner moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ptychomnion aciculare"],"soil":["Watery","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19493,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eupatorium formosanum, like many perennials, prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells or hot summer months, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. Adjust your watering schedule based on rainfall and seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eupatorium formosanum thrives best in full sun to light shade, with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering and growth. When planted in full sun, ensure the soil remains moist to prevent dehydration. However, if the plant is in a location with intense, direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, partial shade during the hottest part of the day can protect it from scorching. If planted in too much shade, the plant may become leggy with fewer flowers. It's crucial to balance sunlight exposure with proper watering for a healthy plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eupatorium formosanum is essential to maintain its shape and encourage robust growth. In early spring, before new growth appears, cut back any dead or damaged stems to the base to encourage fresh growth. Throughout the growing season, pinch back the tips of young shoots to promote bushier growth and more flower production. After the plant has finished flowering, you can also deadhead spent blooms to improve its appearance and potentially encourage a second bloom. In late fall, cut the stems back to about 6 inches above the ground to prepare the plant for winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ground qalanis","description":"Eupatorium formosanum is a plant species in family Asteraceae. It is found in Taiwan and the Ryukyu Islands (Japan). It is a perennial herb growing about 2 m (7 ft) tall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan","East Asia"],"other_name":["ground qalanis"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Eupatorium formosanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

For optimal growth and blooming, place the plant in a location where it receives direct sunlight during the morning and early afternoon. However, in exceedingly hot climates, providing some light afternoon shade can help protect it from intense sunlight stress. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Watsonia tabularis mainly involves cutting back the old flowering stems and dead foliage. Once the flowers fade and the flowering stems begin to die, they can be cut back to the base to encourage healthy growth. This usually happens in late summer to early fall. It's also beneficial to remove any dead or diseased leaves to promote better air circulation and prevent fungal issues. Avoid pruning in the dormancy period, as the plant is not actively growing and does not require shaping or maintenance then."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Table Mountain Watsonia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Table Mountain Watsonia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Watsonia tabularis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers well-drained sandy or rocky soils, and overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. During the tree's first few years, provide deep watering once a week during dry spells. After establishment, natural rainfall is generally sufficient. However, in prolonged drought periods, occasional deep watering may be beneficial. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering to mimic its natural conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus margaretiae thrives in full sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, plant it in a location that receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Full sun exposure encourages a robust structure and denser foliage, enhancing the tree's overall health and appearance. While it can grow in partial shade, its growth rate may slow, and it might become less compact and more open. Ensuring the tree gets adequate sunlight is crucial for its development and resilience against pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus margaretiae should be done to promote a strong structure and remove any damaged or diseased branches. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on thinning the canopy to allow for better air circulation and sunlight penetration. Maintain a single central leader and remove any crossing or rubbing branches. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree. Regular inspections throughout the year can help identify and manage any issues early on, ensuring the tree remains healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sand post oak","description":"Quercus margarettae, the sand post oak or dwarf post oak, is a North American species of oak in the beech family. It thrives in well-drained soil, so avoid letting the soil become waterlogged. During dry spells or extended periods without rain, supplemental watering is beneficial to maintain healthy growth. It’s important to water it deeply but infrequently, encouraging the roots to grow deeper and become more drought-tolerant. Be cautious of overwatering, as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aesculus × carnea thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its robust growth and beautiful flowering. While it can tolerate some shade, too much may result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat. When planting, choose a site that offers optimal sunlight exposure during the day, allowing the plant to develop a strong structure and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aesculus × carnea is usually done to manage its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The ideal time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any crossing or crowded branches to ensure ample air circulation within the canopy. This plant generally requires minimal pruning, but any necessary cuts should be made with clean, sharp tools to minimize stress and potential disease transmission. Regularly inspect the tree and prune away any suckers or lower branches that may interfere with pedestrian or vehicle traffic."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red horse-chestnut","description":"Aesculus × carnea, or red horse-chestnut, is an artificial hybrid between A. pavia (red buckeye) and A. hippocastanum (horse-chestnut). The origin of the tree is not known, but it probably first appeared in Germany before 1820. The hybrid is a medium-size tree to 20–25 m tall, intermediate between the parent species in most respects, but inheriting the red flower color from A. pavia. It is a popular tree in large gardens and parks.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Red horse-chestnut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf blotch","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Aesculus × carnea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It has been known to escape cultivation and become naturalized in areas of appropriate climate; it can be found growing wild in parts of New Zealand and Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Woad-leaved ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Senecio glastifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19699,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viscaria alpina, commonly known as Alpine Catchfly, is a hardy alpine plant that prefers well-drained soil. Overwatering should be avoided as it is adapted to dry, rocky environments. During its active growing season in spring and summer, watering should be moderate, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly to prevent root rot. It is essential to ensure good drainage to mimic its natural habitat, as waterlogged conditions can lead to plant decline. Always observe the plant's condition and adjust watering according to environmental factors like humidity and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viscaria alpina thrives in full sunlight, which mirrors its natural alpine environment. It is best situated in a spot where it can receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. However, it can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. When grown in areas with intense heat, providing some light shading can facilitate healthy growth. Ensuring the plant has access to ample light will encourage vigorous flowering and maintain its robust appearance, important for its overall health and performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viscaria alpina is generally minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. To promote healthy growth and maintain a neat appearance, remove any dead or damaged foliage regularly. After the flowering season, spent flower stems can be trimmed back to encourage new growth and possibly a second bloom. Avoid cutting back the foliage drastically, as it can stress the plant and hinder its growth. Instead, focus on removing any unsightly parts and shaping the plant to ensure it remains healthy and visually appealing. Regular observation will help indicate when pruning is necessary."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Alpine Catchfly","description":"Silene suecica is a species of plant in the Caryophyllaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19395,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ilex asprella, commonly known as the Rough-leaved Holly, prefers consistently moist soil. It is important to water this plant regularly during its growing season, typically spring and summer, ensuring that the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. In the fall and winter, watering can be reduced slightly, as the plant's growth rate diminishes. Always check the top inch of soil before watering; if it feels dry, it's time to water. Use well-draining soil to prevent root rot, which can occur if the plant is left in standing water for too long."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ilex asprella thrives best in locations where it can receive partial to full sun. If planted in a very sunny location, ensure that the soil moisture is adequate to prevent wilting. Too much shade, on the other hand, may result in reduced flowering and slower growth. Finding a balanced location will help this plant flourish."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ilex asprella is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps maintain its shape and encourages fresh, healthy growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Regular light pruning is preferable to occasional heavy pruning, which can harm the plant's development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rough-leaved Holly","description":"Ilex asprella, also known as rough-leaved holly and plum-leaved holly, is a deciduous shrub native in South East Asia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18598,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tetrapanax papyrifer prefers consistently moist soil but doesn’t like to be waterlogged. It is best to water them thoroughly when the top inch of the soil begins to dry out. In hotter climates or during warmer months, this may mean watering several times a week. However, in cooler weather or when the plant is dormant, the frequency may reduce to once a week or less. Ensure the pot has adequate drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tetrapanax papyrifer thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate a few hours of direct morning or late afternoon sun. It prefers dappled light similar to what it would experience in its native understory environment. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window. In very hot climates, ensure it is sheltered from harsh midday sun to prevent leaf scorching. Adjust the light exposure if you notice the leaves are drooping or fading, which can indicate insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tetrapanax papyrifer can help manage its size and encourage a bushier growth habit. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches and trim back overly long stems to maintain the desired shape and size. Throughout the growing season, remove suckers or new shoots at the base if you want to prevent the plant from spreading. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent damage or disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rice paper plant","description":"Tetrapanax papyrifer (rice-paper plant, or 通草—tong cao) is an evergreen shrub in the family Araliaceae, the sole species in the genus Tetrapanax. The specific epithet is frequently misspelled as \"papyriferum\", \"papyriferus\", or \"papyrifera\". It is endemic to Taiwan, but widely cultivated in East Asia and sometimes in other tropical regions as well. The species was once included in the genus Fatsia as Fatsia papyrifera.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan"],"other_name":["Rice paper plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tetrapanax papyrifer"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Fertile"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19097,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Centaurea × moncktonii prefers moderately moist soil but has a good tolerance for drought once established. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During periods of excessive heat or dry spells, you may need to increase the frequency of watering. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can cause root rot. Good drainage is crucial, so ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. Mulching can help retain moisture and maintain even soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Centaurea × moncktonii thrives in full sun to partial shade. It needs at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to perform best in terms of flowering and growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, flowering may be reduced if the plant receives too little light. In extremely hot climates, offering some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. Ideal planting spots are areas that receive morning sun with a bit of protection from harsh, direct sunlight during the peak midday hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Centaurea × moncktonii involves removing faded flowers to encourage continuous blooming and to maintain a tidy appearance. Regular deadheading will prevent the plant from self-seeding too aggressively. In early spring, cut back any old, dead, or damaged stems to ground level to promote new growth and maintain the plant's shape. If the plant becomes leggy, a mid-season trim can encourage bushier growth. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant and prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Monckton's Knapweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Monckton's Knapweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Centaurea × moncktonii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18898,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spinifex sericeus, or coastal spinifex, is a hardy plant typically found in sand dune ecosystems. It is very drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. Overwatering can harm the plant, so it is best to let the soil dry out between waterings. During the growing season, particularly in spring and summer, a moderate watering once every two to three weeks, or only when the soil appears dry, should suffice. Ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which could damage the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spinifex sericeus thrives in full sunlight and can tolerate harsh coastal conditions, including intense sun exposure. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. While it can handle partial shade, prolonged lack of sufficient sunlight can result in stunted growth and reduce its vigor. In its natural habitat, it is exposed to uninterrupted sunlight, so mimic these conditions by placing it in an open, sunny location to promote healthy development and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spinifex sericeus is generally not necessary except to control its spread or to remove dead or damaged foliage. If pruning is required, it is best to do so after its flowering season, around late summer or early autumn. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Regular pruning isn’t essential, but occasional trimming helps maintain the desired shape and can encourage new growth if needed. Always avoid cutting too much of the plant at once to prevent stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beach Spinifex","description":"Spinifex sericeus, commonly known as hairy spinifex, rolling spinifex, beach spinifex or coastal spinifex, is a dioecious perennial grass.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Beach Spinifex"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Spinifex sericeus"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18301,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clerodendrum paniculatum, commonly known as the Pagoda flower, prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, allowing the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. This means you might need to water it more frequently during warmer months and less during the winter. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent root rot. Adjust the watering schedule based on the season and environmental humidity; in drier conditions, the plant may require more frequent watering to maintain adequate moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clerodendrum paniculatum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct morning sunlight, but excessive direct sun, particularly during midday, can scorch its leaves or cause them to become crispy. Therefore, it's best to position this plant in a spot where it receives filtered sunlight or partial shade. Indoors, a location near a window with plenty of indirect light works well, while outdoors, it's ideal to plant it under the dappled shade of taller plants or trees to mimic its natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clerodendrum paniculatum is crucial to maintain its shape and encourage more prolific blooming. Prune the plant in spring or after flowering to remove any dead or damaged branches. This will also help in controlling its size and shape, as it can become quite bushy. Cut back to a set of leaves or a lateral branch to promote fuller growth. Water the plant deeply but infrequently to ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Ensure the soil drains well to prevent root rot. Use lukewarm water to avoid shocking the plant's roots and always monitor the moisture levels to adjust watering frequency accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phoenix loureiroi thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure all sides receive adequate sunlight for even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is necessary to maintain the healthy growth of Phoenix loureiroi. Remove any dead or brown fronds near the base of the plant to improve its appearance and prevent disease. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut fronds close to the trunk without damaging it. During the active growing season in spring and summer, aim to water when the top inch of soil feels dry. Be cautious in the fall and winter months, reducing watering frequency to prevent root rot while the plant is dormant. Maintaining an even moisture level is crucial, as erratic watering can stress the plant and negatively affect its growth. Always ensure the pot or ground area has adequate drainage to avoid standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio ovatus thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions. Ideally, it should receive sunlight for at least four to six hours a day. While it can tolerate full sun, especially in cooler climates, in hotter regions, providing protection from the intense afternoon sun is beneficial to prevent sunburn or dehydration stress. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a bright window with filtered light is recommended. Too little light can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensuring an adequate amount of sunlight is crucial for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio ovatus primarily involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. This can be done throughout the growing season. Prune after the flowering period to encourage bushier growth and possibly a second blooming cycle. It's also advisable to cut back any overly vigorous stalks early in the growing season to manage growth form. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts, ensuring clean wounds and reducing the risk of disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wood Ragwort","description":"Senecio ovatus, common name wood ragwort, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Wood Ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Senecio ovatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19296,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aloidendron dichotomum, commonly known as the quiver tree, is drought-tolerant and does well with infrequent but deep watering. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant thoroughly every two to three weeks, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In winter, significantly reduce watering, as the plant goes dormant and can be prone to root rot in cold, wet conditions. Ensure the pot or ground has excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging, which this succulent is particularly sensitive to."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aloidendron dichotomum thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is accustomed to hot, arid environments and can tolerate very bright light conditions, making it ideal for open, sunny locations in a garden or near a south-facing window indoors. Insufficient sunlight can lead to weak, leggy growth, so if grown indoors, place the plant in the brightest spot available. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may prevent scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aloidendron dichotomum is generally minimal. Remove only dead or damaged leaves close to their base, using clean, sharp scissors or garden shears to avoid transmitting diseases. It's important to prune cautiously because over-pruning can stress the plant. Ensure any pruned areas are dry to reduce the risk of infection, particularly during the rainy season. Only prune in late winter or early spring before the plant enters its active growth phase, as this timing helps the plant recover more quickly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Quiver Tree","description":"Aloidendron dichotomum, formerly Aloe dichotoma, the quiver tree or kokerboom, is a tall, branching species of succulent plant, indigenous to Southern Africa, specifically in the Northern Cape region of South Africa, and parts of Southern Namibia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Namibia","South Africa"],"other_name":["Quiver Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Aloidendron dichotomum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It’s advisable to prune in early spring or late fall. Use a pair of gloves and sharp pruners to remove any yellowing leaves or dead stems. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation and can prevent the plant from becoming too invasive, as nettles tend to spread quickly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese Nettle","description":"Urtica thunbergiana is a species of the genus Urtica. It is found in Japan, China and Taiwan. The habitat if the species is moist forests in the mountains. It is in flower from July to September, and its seeds ripen from August to October. The larvae of Vanessa indica, a species of butterfly, are known to feed on U. thunbergiana.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan","Taiwan"],"other_name":["Japanese Nettle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider Mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Urtica thunbergiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19600,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Reynoutria sachalinensis, also known as giant knotweed, prefers consistently moist soil. Water the plant deeply at least once a week, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During dry periods or when the plant is actively growing in the spring and summer, more frequent watering may be necessary. Ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can cause root rot. Using mulch around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature, providing a more stable environment for root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Reynoutria sachalinensis thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. However, it can tolerate some degree of shade, particularly in hotter climates, where partial shade can help prevent leaf scorch due to intense sunlight. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and less vigorous. Ensure it is planted where it can receive some direct sunlight, particularly in the mornings, to maintain its robust growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Reynoutria sachalinensis is essential to control its vigorous growth and prevent it from becoming invasive. It's best to prune the plant in late autumn or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the stems to ground level to encourage fresh growth and manage size. Regularly remove any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth. Additionally, remove any unwanted shoots throughout the growing season to control spread. Proper disposal of pruned material is important as cuttings can root and propagate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Giant Knotweed","description":"Reynoutria sachalinensis (giant knotweed or Sakhalin knotweed Japanese オオイタドリ ooitadori, Russian Горец сахалинский, Гречиха сахалинская; syns. Polygonum sachalinense, Fallopia sachalinensis) is a species of Fallopia native to northeastern Asia in northern Japan (Hokkaidō, Honshū) and the far east of Russia (Sakhalin and the southern Kurile Islands).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Japan","China","Korea","Sakhalin Island"],"other_name":["Giant Knotweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Root cuttings","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Reynoutria sachalinensis"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
